commit_message:
Add callback to allow controller notification of allocation change

This patch adds a simple callback mechanism to allow the controller
embedding a transfer table to be notified when the allocation in
the table has changed.

This is needed so that panels in the launch instance wizard can
update the launch instance model when the allocation changes.

Change-Id: I2c6fc35aedeeb9e58e2f08fafa293bc45cdd92af
Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/09/162009/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * allocatedChanged: function (allocated) { * ... * }, * When the allocated set is changed the allocatedChanged callback will * be invoked (if defined) and passed the transfer table's current * allocated array. * // let listener know the allocation has changed if (angular.isDefined(trModel.allocatedChanged)) { trModel.allocatedChanged(trModel.allocated); } // Suppress the emit event as we'll generate one on allocate() model.deallocate(trModel.allocated[0], true); model.deallocate = function(row, suppress_emit) { // let listeners know the allocation has changed if (suppress_emit !== true) { if (angular.isDefined(trModel.allocatedChanged)) { trModel.allocatedChanged(trModel.allocated); } }

commit_message:
Fix Etag check on EC put for if_none_match

EC put should check for the whole object etag(X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Etag)

Change-Id: I7a9f0fe5b61eaf530b54f5a1854936237a556c2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/05/162905/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_PUT_if_none_match_ec(self): # PUT with if-none-match set and nothing there should succeed timestamp = normalize_timestamp(time()) req = Request.blank( '/sda1/p/a/c/o', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'PUT'}, headers={'X-Timestamp': timestamp, 'Content-Length': '6', 'Content-Type': 'application/octet-stream', 'X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Etag': 'ecetag', 'If-None-Match': 'ecetag'}) req.body = 'VERIFY' resp = req.get_response(self.object_controller) self.assertEquals(resp.status_int, 201) # PUT with if-none-match of the object etag should fail timestamp = normalize_timestamp(time()) req = Request.blank( '/sda1/p/a/c/o', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'PUT'}, headers={'X-Timestamp': timestamp, 'Content-Length': '6', 'Content-Type': 'application/octet-stream', 'X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Etag': 'ecetag', 'If-None-Match': 'ecetag'}) req.body = 'VERIFY' resp = req.get_response(self.object_controller) self.assertEquals(resp.status_int, 412)

commit_message:
Make sure we don't log the full content of the config drive

The config drive content can be pretty heavy, so let's make sure we
don't log it.

Plus, this commit is changing the log level from INFO to DEBUG, which
is the right one for that message.

Closes-Bug: #1429208
Change-Id: I383886a72b3930b261c02027c8c93779432b3e45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/52/162252/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(lucasagomes): Let's make sure we don't log the full content # of the config drive here because it can we be up to 64MB in size, # so instead let's log "True" in case config drive is enabled. if LOG.isEnabledFor(logging.logging.DEBUG): log_params = params.copy() if 'configdrive' in log_params: params['configdrive'] = True LOG.debug('Continuing deployment for node %(node)s, params %(params)s', {'node': node.uuid, 'params': log_params})
deleted_lines: LOG.info(_LI('Continuing deployment for node %(node)s, params %(params)s'), {'node': node.uuid, 'params': params})

Adds [upload_sphinx] in setup.cfg

Adding the Sphinx upload-dir to setup.cfg allow us
compiling Trove developers docs.

Closes-Bug: #1430584

commit_message:
Temporarily pinning oslo.log and adding tempest-lib

This will probably fail the requirements (non-voting) gate, but this
should get things running for the moment. I'm looking to follow this up
with a permanent fix.

Change-Id: I496b7736759928329affaecbcc29254619fd3e5f

commit_message:
Neutron LBaaS: Creating Health Monitor API Tests

Creating health monitor API tests

Change-Id: I7784d84ef27f2ac6d570700553e7f389931857c3
Co-Authored-By: Carlos D. Garza <carlos.garza@rackspace.com>
Co-Authored-By: Franklin Naval <franklin.naval@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/73/156773/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.v2.api import base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest import exceptions as ex from tempest import test class TestHealthMonitors(base.BaseTestCase): """ Tests the following operations in the Neutron-LBaaS API using the REST client for Health Monitors: list pools create pool get pool update pool delete pool """ @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(TestHealthMonitors, cls).resource_setup() if not test.is_extension_enabled('lbaas', 'network'): msg = "lbaas extension not enabled." raise cls.skipException(msg) network_name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') cls.network = cls.create_network(network_name) cls.subnet = cls.create_subnet(cls.network) cls.load_balancer = cls._create_load_balancer( tenant_id=cls.subnet.get('tenant_id'), vip_subnet_id=cls.subnet.get('id')) cls._wait_for_load_balancer_status(cls.load_balancer.get('id')) cls.listener = cls.listeners_client.create_listener( loadbalancer_id=cls.load_balancer.get('id'), protocol='HTTP', protocol_port=80) cls._wait_for_load_balancer_status(cls.load_balancer.get('id')) cls.pool = cls.pools_client.create_pool( protocol='HTTP', lb_algorithm='ROUND_ROBIN', listener_id=cls.listener.get('id')) cls._wait_for_load_balancer_status(cls.load_balancer.get('id')) def _create_healthmonitor(self, **kwargs): return self.health_monitors_client.create_health_monitor(**kwargs) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_list_health_monitors_empty(self): hm_list = self.health_monitors_client.list_health_monitors() self.assertEmpty(hm_list) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_list_health_monitors_one(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) hm_list = self.health_monitors_client.list_health_monitors() self.assertIn(hm, hm_list) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_list_health_monitors_two(self): hm1 = self._create_healthmonitor( type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) new_listener = self.listeners_client.create_listener( loadbalancer_id=self.load_balancer.get('id'), protocol='HTTP', protocol_port=88) new_pool = self.pools_client.create_pool( protocol='HTTP', lb_algorithm='ROUND_ROBIN', listener_id=new_listener.get('id')) hm2 = self._create_healthmonitor( type='HTTP', max_retries=10, delay=3, timeout=5, pool_id=new_pool.get('id')) hm_list = self.health_monitors_client.list_health_monitors() self.assertEqual(2, len(hm_list)) self.assertIn(hm1, hm_list) self.assertIn(hm2, hm_list) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm1.get('id')) self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm2.get('id')) self.pools_client.delete_pool(new_pool.get('id')) self.listeners_client.delete_listener(new_listener.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_get_health_monitor(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) hm_test = self.health_monitors_client.get_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) self.assertEqual(hm, hm_test) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_create_health_monitor(self): new_hm = self._create_healthmonitor( type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) hm = self.health_monitors_client.get_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) self.assertEqual(new_hm, hm) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_create_health_monitor_missing_attribute(self): new_hm = self._create_healthmonitor( type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) hm = self.health_monitors_client.get_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) self.assertEqual(new_hm, hm) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_create_health_monitor_invalid_attribute(self): new_hm = self._create_healthmonitor( type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) hm = self.health_monitors_client.get_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) self.assertEqual(new_hm, hm) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_create_health_monitor_extra_attribute(self): new_hm = self._create_healthmonitor( type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) hm = self.health_monitors_client.get_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) self.assertEqual(new_hm, hm) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_update_health_monitor(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) max_retries = 1 new_hm = self.health_monitors_client.update_health_monitor( hm.get('id'), max_retries=max_retries) self.assertEqual(max_retries, new_hm.get('max_retries')) # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(new_hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_udpate_health_monitor_invalid_attribute(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) self.assertRaises(ex.BadRequest, self.health_monitors_client.update_health_monitor, hm.get('id'), max_retries='blue') # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_update_health_monitor_extra_attribute(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) self.assertRaises(ex.BadRequest, self.health_monitors_client.update_health_monitor, hm.get('id'), protocol='UDP') # cleanup test self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_delete_health_monitor(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) self.assertRaises(ex.NotFound, self.health_monitors_client.get_health_monitor, hm.get('id')) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_delete_missing_health_monitor(self): hm = self._create_healthmonitor(type='HTTP', delay=3, max_retries=10, timeout=5, pool_id=self.pool.get('id')) self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor(hm.get('id')) self.assertRaises(ex.NotFound, self.health_monitors_client.delete_health_monitor, hm.get('id'))

commit_message:
Neutron LBaaS: Initial Load Balancer Tests

* contains initial load balancer tests
* some bug fixes to client
* in resouce cleanup, added a try/except around
  the lb statuses query in case we delete the
  load balancer prior to clean up

Co-Authored-By: Trevor Vardemon  <trevor.vardeman@RACKSPACE.COM>
Co-Authored-By: Carlos Garza  <carlos.garza@RACKSPACE.COM>
Change-Id: Id22372138896925749a9fd2cab4a80e33ec315b3

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.v2.api import base from tempest import config from tempest import test from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.openstack.common import log as logging CONF = config.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class LoadBalancerTestJSON(base.BaseTestCase): """ Tests the following operations in the Neutron-LBaaS API using the REST client for Load Balancers: list load balancers create load balancer get load balancer update load balancer delete load balancer """ @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(LoadBalancerTestJSON, cls).resource_setup() if not test.is_extension_enabled('lbaas', 'network'): msg = "lbaas extension not enabled." raise cls.skipException(msg) cls.network = cls.create_network() network_name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') cls.name = cls.network[network_name] cls.subnet = cls.create_subnet(cls.network) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_list_load_balancers(self): # The list load balancers load_balancers = self.load_balancers_client.list_load_balancers() self.assertEquals(0, len(load_balancers))

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.v2.clients.pools_client as pools_client from tempest import test import testtools class TestPools(testtools.TestCase): def setup(self): self.client = pools_client.PoolsClientJSON() @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_list_pools(self): """Test get all pools""" body = self.client.list_pools() pools = body.get('pools') self.assertIsNone(pools)

commit_message:
Added tox tempest environment

When running tox with tox -etempest, tox will install tempest
from a specific commit that the v2 tests are known to work well
with.  Then the tests will be run. This also puts a change in
pretty_tox.sh to control the concurrency level because the
tempest tests will fail when running in parallel.

Change-Id: I745293322149390f0e709165f34c144f5c439720
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/72/162772/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #This is for supporting tempest tests in tox as the neutron-lbaas tempest tests fail when run in parallel CONCURRENCY=${OS_TESTR_CONCURRENCY:-} if [ -n "$CONCURRENCY" ] then CONCURRENCY="--concurrency=$CONCURRENCY" fistatus=$(exec 4>&1 >&3; (python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args="--subunit $TESTRARGS $CONCURRENCY"; echo $? >&4 ) | $(dirname $0)/subunit-trace.py -f) && exit $status

MetaData, schema, Table from nova.i18n import _LI LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) UNIQUES = [ ('services', "uniq_services0host0topic0deleted", ["host", "topic", "deleted"]), ('services', 'uniq_instances0uuid', ['uuid']), ('instance_info_caches', "uniq_instance_info_caches0instance_uuid", ['instance_uuid']), ("instance_types", "uniq_instance_types0flavorid0deleted", ["flavorid", commit_message:
Datestamp the generated test image

Copying to tarballs.openstack.org is not atomic, so the image
name needs to include a datestamp and the publish mechanism needs
to symlink to the lastest image.

Change-Id: I7ffba492812beca39cdb773d9e284750a3a80878
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/82/163182/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export IMAGE_NAME=${IMAGE_NAME:-$DISTRO-heat-test-image-`date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S`}

commit_message:
Glance containers need to be changed so they work without kubernetes

This patch overlaps a little bit with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/162358/.
There were some additional glance config that needs to be added to run without
kubernetes.

Co-authored by: Charles Crouch (charcrou@cisco.com)
Change-Id: I1aab2f6e4a80aaf1e6c4b7fe330bcf9a7740fdc6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/84/163184/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: : ${GLANCE_API_SERVICE_HOST:=$PUBLIC_IP} /opt/kolla/wait_for 30 1 keystone \ --os-auth-url=http://${KEYSTONE_PUBLIC_SERVICE_HOST}:35357/v2.0 \ --os-username=admin --os-tenant-name=${ADMIN_TENANT_NAME} \ --os-password=${KEYSTONE_ADMIN_PASSWORD} endpoint-list# turn on notification sending by glance crudini --set /etc/glance/glance-api.conf \ DEFAULT \ notification_driver \ "messaging" crudini --set /etc/glance/glance-api.conf \ DEFAULT \ rabbit_host \ "${RABBITMQ_SERVICE_HOST}" crudini --set /etc/glance/glance-api.conf \ DEFAULT \ registry_host \ "${GLANCE_REGISTRY_SERVICE_HOST}" crudini --set /etc/glance/glance-api.conf \ DEFAULT \ debug \ "True"

commit_message:
added security group to create cluster call

- Added a configuration item, os_security_group, to api to allow
  a default security group to be specified
- Added tests to test_create_vm to verify invalid security group
  results in a failure
- Modified nova fixture to check for security_groups in vm create
- Modified neutron create port to include security_groups
- Modified devstack plugin to create a security group for rabbitmq

Change-Id: Ib8490b15b0e90812d630d237cc4fcc8d0c8a4f9a

commit_message:
Delete assemblies when plan is deleted

Presently deleting a plan (app) fails if any
assemblies, READY or otherwise, reference that plan.

This patch adds a destroy_app function to deployer
to asynchronously delete a plan's assemblies before
deleting the plan. The existing destroy function
has been renamed to destroy_assembly to reduce
confusion.

Closes-Bug: 1422500

Change-Id: Idc10e317c0502001ef847b38b690cf67e9826022
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/01/160501/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from solum.api.handlers import assembly_handler p_handler = plan_handler.PlanHandler(pecan.request.security_context) try: p_handler.delete(self._id) except (db_exc.DBError): except (db_exc.DBReferenceError): plan_obj = p_handler.get(self._id) a_handler = assembly_handler.AssemblyHandler( pecan.request.security_context) assemblies = [a for a in a_handler.get_all() if a.plan_id == plan_obj.id] while assemblies: for assembly in assemblies: a_handler.delete(assembly.uuid) assemblies = [a for a in a_handler.get_all() if a.plan_id == plan_obj.id] p_handler.delete(self._id) pecan.response.status = 202

commit_message:
Mock RPC _send method in BaseTestCase

The purpose of this patch is to get rid of this sort of spam:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/183145/
I don't understand the deal with the fake RPC transport.
It's sending out a message, and waiting for a reply from... Who?
One solution is to just mock the _send method of the fake RPC transport.
Another would be to change the behavior in the Oslo messaging fake driver.

Change-Id: I22227f19c347b3f43cbea214249f29eba4dccc09

subject: Fix time issue in AccessInfo test
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-10 18:44:46.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/test_access.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/932e6d551068b0a1956d0d8dd6af85513bb96587', 'message': "Fix time issue in AccessInfo test

I've only seen this happen once, however by making the token expiry 5
minutes in the future, then checking that it wont have expired in 300
seconds means that if the test happens all on the same second boundary
then the test will fail.

Just increase the time we're checking for by a second to ensure it
doesn't happen.

Change-Id: Iadeadfbacaf6f1b939c237919b52445c60c9bdd0
"}]
commit_message:
Fix time issue in AccessInfo test

I've only seen this happen once, however by making the token expiry 5
minutes in the future, then checking that it wont have expired in 300
seconds means that if the test happens all on the same second boundary
then the test will fail.

Just increase the time we're checking for by a second to ensure it
doesn't happen.

Change-Id: Iadeadfbacaf6f1b939c237919b52445c60c9bdd0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/28/163128/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Modify Cisco CSR1kv device driver to use REST API

Change the Cisco CSR1kv routing device driver from using NETCONF to
using REST API for configuration

Change-Id: I03c61b9e7232e4f753b73b732ab4c1ec12fb0dbe
Closes-Bug: 1363265
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/31/115431/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # @author: Hareesh Puthalath, Tom Holtzen Cisco Systems, Inc.import requestsfrom neutron.plugins.cisco.cfg_agent.device_driver import devicedriver_api from neutron.plugins.cisco.cfg_agent.device_drivers import csr1kv_rest_client#STATUS_OPTS = [ # cfg.IntOpt('csr1kv_rest_port', default=55443, # help=_("Default port for connecting to via the REST API")), #] cfg.CONF.register_opts(STATUS_OPTS) This driver encapsulates the configuration logic via REST API to settings = {'rest_mgmt': device_params['management_ip_address'] + ':55443', 'username': credentials['username'], 'password': credentials['password'], 'timeout': cfg.CONF.device_connection_timeout} self.csr = csr1kv_rest_client.CsrRestClient(settings) except (KeyError, Exception) as e: self._enable_intfs() # Finally, remove external network subinterface self._csr_add_floating_ip(ri, ex_gw_port, floating_ip, fixed_ip) gateway_ip, netmask) self._nat_rules_for_internet_access(internal_net, netmask, inner_intfc, outer_intfc, vrf_name) in_intfc_name = None if in_intfc_name: vrf_name = self._csr_get_vrf_name(ri) self._remove_dyn_nat_rule(in_intfc_name, vrf_name) def _csr_add_floating_ip(self, ri, ex_gw_port, floating_ip, fixed_ip): Interfaces in the CSR1kv are created in pairs (T1 and T2) where T1 interface is used for VLAN and T2 interface for VXLAN traffic respectively. On the neutron side these are named T1 and T2 ports and follows the naming convention: <Tx_PORT_NAME_PREFIX>:<PAIR_INDEX> where the `PORT_NAME_PREFIX` indicates either VLAN or VXLAN and `PAIR_INDEX` is the pair number. `PAIR_INDEX` starts at 1. In CSR1kv, GigabitEthernet 0 is not present and GigabitEthernet 1 is used as a management interface (Note: this might change in future). So the first (T1,T2) pair corresponds to (GigabitEthernet 2, GigabitEthernet 3) and so forth. This function extracts the `PAIR_INDEX` and calculates the corresponding interface number. response = self.csr.get_request('interfaces/%s' % interface) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.OK and response: return True return False def _enable_intfs(self): Only the second and third Gig interfaces are enabled now, as these are configured as trunk for VLAN and VXLAN and hence the only ones needed now. Note: CSR1kv, in release 3.11 GigabitEthernet 0 is no longer present. So GigabitEthernet 1 is used as management and GigabitEthernet 2 and up are used for data. This might change on future releases. #ToDo(Hareesh): Interfaces are hard coded for now. interface_names = ['GigabitEthernet2', 'GigabitEthernet3'] for i in interface_names: response = self.csr.get_request('interfaces/%s/state' % i) if response and not response['enabled']: state_info = {u'if-name': i, u'enabled': True} response = self.csr.put_request('interfaces/%s/state' % i, payload=state_info) self._check_response(response) response = self.csr.get_request('vrf') LOG.debug("Interface get response %s" % response) if response: for vrf in response['items']: vrfs.append(vrf['name']) def _check_acl(self, acl_addr): Acls are returned in a collection of items, with each item containing a list of rules :param acl_addr: netaddr.IPNetwork(network/netmask) for acl :return: None or acl id acl_list = self.csr.get_request('acl') self._check_response(acl_list) if len(acl_list['items']): for acl in acl_list['items']: for rule in acl['rules']: address = rule['source'].split('/')[0] mask = rule['source'].split('/')[1] hostmask_len = 32 - acl_addr.prefixlen if rule['action'] == 'permit' and \ address == str(acl_addr.network) and \ mask == str(hostmask_len) and \ rule['destination'] == '0.0.0.0/32': return acl['acl-id'] LOG.debug("%s ACL is not present", str(acl_addr.cidr)) return None vrf_info = {u'name': vrf_name} response = self.csr.get_request('vrf/%s' % vrf_name) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.NOT_FOUND: response = self.csr.post_request('vrf', payload=vrf_info) self._check_response(response) LOG.info(_("VRF %s successfully created"), vrf_name) response = self.csr.delete_request('vrf/%s' % vrf_name) self._check_response(response) LOG.info(_("VRF %s successfully deleted"), vrf_name) # VRF was not initially present, try to create it LOG.warning(_("VRF %s not present"), vrf_name) self._create_vrf(vrf_name) if self.csr.status != requests.codes.OK: LOG.exception(_("VRF %s not created"), vrf_name) msg = "VRF %s not created" % vrf_name raise cfg_exc.CSR1kvConfigException(msg) self.csr.get_request('interfaces/%s' % subinterface) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.NOT_FOUND: # only create the subinterface if it does not exist vlan_info = {u'encap-type': 'DOT1Q', u'vlan-id': vlan_id} subinterface_info = {u'type': u'ethernet', u'if-name': subinterface, u'ip-address': ip, u'subnet-mask': mask, u'subinterface-vlan': vlan_info} response = self.csr.post_request('interfaces', payload=subinterface_info) self._check_response(response) vrf_info = self.csr.get_request('vrf/%s' % vrf_name) if subinterface in vrf_info['forwarding']: # no need to apply the forwarding, if it's already there return # Need to save off all previously configured interfaces on the parent # interface, then re-apply the ip address, as the vrf forwarding wipes # them out due to the REST API implementation intfc_prefix = subinterface.split('.')[0] + '.' interfaces = [] response = self.csr.get_request('interfaces') # get all the subinterface info for interface in response['items']: if interface['if-name'].startswith(intfc_prefix, 0, len(interface['if-name'])): del interface['kind'] interfaces.append(interface) # apply the vrf forwarding for the subinterface forwarding = vrf_info['forwarding'] forwarding.append(subinterface) vrf_update = {'forwarding': forwarding} response = self.csr.put_request('vrf/%s' % vrf_name, payload=vrf_update) self._check_response(response) # re-apply the required ip addresses for interface in interfaces: response = self.csr.put_request('interfaces/%s' % interface['if-name'], payload=interface) self._check_response(response) if self._interface_exists(subinterface): response = self.csr.delete_request('interfaces/%s' % subinterface) self._check_response(response) LOG.error(_("VRF %s not present") % vrf_name) msg = "VRF %s does not exist" % vrf_name raise cfg_exc.CSR1kvConfigException(msg) ha_info = {u'virtual-ip-address': ip, u'interface-name': subinterface, u'version': 2, u'group': group, u'priority': priority, u'name': vrf_name + "-group"} response = self.csr.post_request('hsrp', payload=ha_info) self._check_response(response) def _nat_rules_for_internet_access(self, network, netmask, inner_intfc, outer_intfc, vrf_name): Configuring NAT rules in the CSR1kv is a four step process. First ACL and VRF of the neutron router. Then enable NAT on the interfaces of the CSR where the internal and external networks are connected. :raises: neutron.plugins.cisco.l3.exceptions.CSR1kvConfigException acl_addr = netaddr.IPNetwork(str(network) + '/' + str(netmask)) acl_id = self._check_acl(acl_addr) if not acl_id: rule_info = {u'action': u'permit', u'source': str(acl_addr.cidr), u'destination': 'any', u'protocol': 'all', u'sequence': '10'} acl_info = {u'rules': [rule_info]} response = self.csr.post_request('acl', payload=acl_info) self._check_response(response) # The ACL id is returned in the response as below # Location: http://host/api/v1/acl-svc/acl/acl-id acl_location_str = response.split('/') acl_id = acl_location_str[len(acl_location_str) - 1] outer_intfc_info = self.csr.get_request('interfaces/%s' % outer_intfc) # need to use nat pool as NAT on an interface does not exist # for REST API yet response = self.csr.get_request('nat-svc/pool/%s' % 'pool-' + inner_intfc) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.NOT_FOUND: pool_info = {u'nat-pool-id': 'pool-' + inner_intfc, u'start-ip-address': outer_intfc_info['ip-address'], u'end-ip-address': outer_intfc_info['ip-address'], u'prefix-length': 24} response = self.csr.post_request('nat-svc/pool', payload=pool_info) self._check_response(response) # create the rule to NAT all internal address to the outer pool address response = self.csr.get_request('/vrf/%s/nat-svc/dynamic/%s' % (vrf_name, 'nat-' + inner_intfc)) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.NOT_FOUND: nat_info = {u'nat-rule-id': 'nat-' + inner_intfc, u'mode': 'inside-source', u'acl-id': acl_id, u'nat-pool-id': 'pool-' + inner_intfc, u'pat-enabled': True} response = self.csr.post_request('/vrf/%s/nat-svc/dynamic' % vrf_name, payload=nat_info) self._check_response(response) # apply the nat direction to the inner and outer interfaces self._add_interface_nat(inner_intfc, 'inside') self._add_interface_nat(outer_intfc, 'outside') nat_intfc_info = self.csr.get_request('interfaces/%s' % intfc_name) if nat_intfc_info['nat-direction'] != intfc_type: nat_intfc_info['nat-direction'] = intfc_type del nat_intfc_info['kind'] response = self.csr.put_request('interfaces/' + intfc_name, payload=nat_intfc_info) self._check_response(response) if self._interface_exists(intfc_name): nat_intfc_info = self.csr.get_request('interfaces/%s' % intfc_name) if nat_intfc_info['nat-direction'] == intfc_type: nat_intfc_info['nat-direction'] = '' del nat_intfc_info['kind'] response = self.csr.put_request('interfaces/%s' % intfc_name, payload=nat_intfc_info) self._check_response(response) def _remove_dyn_nat_rule(self, in_intfc_name, vrf_name): nat_dynm_info = self.csr.get_request('/vrf/%s/nat-svc/dynamic/%s' % (vrf_name, 'nat-' + in_intfc_name)) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.OK: response = self.csr.delete_request('/vrf/%s/nat-svc/dynamic/%s' % (vrf_name, 'nat-' + in_intfc_name)) self._check_response(response) # remove the nat pool associated with the dynamic nat rule response = self.csr.delete_request('nat-svc/pool/%s' % nat_dynm_info['nat-pool-id']) self._check_response(response) # remove the acl associated with the dynamic nat rule response = self.csr.delete_request('acl/%s' % nat_dynm_info['acl-id']) self._check_response(response) action_info = {u'action': 'clear'} response = self.csr.post_request('nat-svc/translations', payload=action_info) self._check_response(response) response = self.csr.get_request('vrf/%s/nat-svc/static/%s' % (vrf, 'static-' + floating_ip)) if self.csr.status == requests.codes.NOT_FOUND: ip_mapping_info = {u'local-ip': fixed_ip, u'global-ip': floating_ip} nat_static_info = {u'nat-rule-id': 'static-' + floating_ip, u'mode': 'inside-source', u'ip-mapping': ip_mapping_info, u'match-in-vrf': True} response = self.csr.post_request('vrf/%s/nat-svc/static' % vrf, payload=nat_static_info) self._check_response(response) response = self.csr.delete_request('vrf/%s/nat-svc/static/%s' % (vrf, 'static-' + floating_ip)) self._check_response(response) ip = netaddr.IPNetwork(str(dest) + '/' + str(dest_mask)) static_route_info = {u'destination-network': str(ip.cidr), u'next-hop-router': next_hop} response = self.csr.post_request('vrf/%s/routing-svc/static-routes' % vrf, payload=static_route_info) self._check_response(response) ip = netaddr.IPNetwork(str(dest) + '/' + str(dest_mask)) resp = self.csr.delete_request('vrf/%s/routing-svc/static-routes/%s' % (vrf, str(dest) + '_' + str(ip.prefixlen) + '_' + str(next_hop))) self._check_response(resp) static_route_info = {u'destination-network': '0.0.0.0/32', u'next-hop-router': gw_ip} response = self.csr.post_request('vrf/%s/routing-svc/static-routes' % vrf, payload=static_route_info) self._check_response(response) The external ncclient library is used for creating this connection. This method keeps state of any existing connections and reuses them if already connected. Also CSR1kv's interfaces (except management) are disabled by default when it is booted. So if connecting for the first time, driver will enable all other interfaces and keep that status in the `_intfs_enabled` flag. """ try: if self._csr_conn and self._csr_conn.connected: return self._csr_conn else: self._csr_conn = manager.connect(host=self._csr_host, port=self._csr_ssh_port, username=self._csr_user, password=self._csr_password, device_params={'name': "csr"}, timeout=self._timeout) if not self._intfs_enabled: self._intfs_enabled = self._enable_intfs(self._csr_conn) return self._csr_conn except Exception as e: conn_params = {'host': self._csr_host, 'port': self._csr_ssh_port, 'user': self._csr_user, 'timeout': self._timeout, 'reason': e.message} raise cfg_exc.CSR1kvConnectionException(**conn_params) Interfaces in the CSR1kv are created in pairs (T1 and T2) where T1 interface is used for VLAN and T2 interface for VXLAN traffic respectively. In CSR1kv, GigabitEthernet 0 is not present and GigabitEthernet 1 is used as a management interface (Note: this might change in future). We take the error type and tag. <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rpc-reply message-id="urn:uuid:81bf8082-....-b69a-000c29e1b85c" xmlns="urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.0"> <rpc-error> <error-type>protocol</error-type> <error-tag>operation-failed</error-tag> <error-severity>error</error-severity> </rpc-error> </rpc-reply> :raises: neutron.plugins.cisco.cfg_agent.cfg_exceptions. commit_message:
Modified "remote" column in the secgroup table

Replaced Remote column in the security group rule table with two
columns "Remote IP Prefix" and "Remote Security Group" to provide
clear details to the user.

Closes-Bug: #1378878

Change-Id: Id62c89c071db2d43b1186016d8c17337ecf5fb13

commit_message:
Add mismatch arguments in inherited dashboard classes

Add:
* extra_context in the SetFlavorChoiceAction.get_help_text
    (panel project.instances) ;
* form_class (kwargs) in the EditAttachmentsView.get_form
    (panel project.volumes).

Those arguments were missing in children classes.

Change-Id: I6d98feaae418e4d1aeed52ab2d6fce3427f481f6
Closes-Bug: #1335180
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/16/107616/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_form(self, **kwargs): form_class = kwargs.get('form_class', self.get_form_class())

This is needed to avoid test cases breaking policy file search code from
oslo.config by mocking out stdlib functions from os module like
os.path.isdir or os.path.exists.

This also allows us to remove explicit policy setup from test_api_v2 and
test_policy files.

Note that for test_netns_cleanup, test_ovs_cleanup, and test_config, we
removed test_setup_conf test cases. They test a function that is used in
other test cases only, and hence do not belong to the suite. This allows
us to avoid hacks around those test cases that do not play nice with
global config-file options we set in BaseTestCase.

removed test_setup_conf test cases. They test a function that is used in
other test cases only, and hence do not belong to the suite. This allows
us to avoid hacks around those test cases that do not play nice with
global config-file options we set in BaseTestCase.

Change-Id: If14a3c741837193ad104467f0cf4486a6a386e6d
Closes-Bug: #1426369
'}]
commit_message:
tests: initialize policy in BaseTestCase

This is needed to avoid test cases breaking policy file search code from
oslo.config by mocking out stdlib functions from os module like
os.path.isdir or os.path.exists.

This also allows us to remove explicit policy setup from test_api_v2 and
test_policy files.

Note that for test_netns_cleanup, test_ovs_cleanup, and test_config, we
removed test_setup_conf test cases. They test a function that is used in
other test cases only, and hence do not belong to the suite. This allows
us to avoid hacks around those test cases that do not play nice with
global config-file options we set in BaseTestCase.

Change-Id: If14a3c741837193ad104467f0cf4486a6a386e6d
Closes-Bug: #1426369
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/63/159863/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
policy: don't hack around oslo.config path search algorithm

Instead, pass proper --config-file when running tests. This should
make oslo_config.ConfigOpts.find_file work even when running from the
source tree.

Change-Id: I24e36170e6f289ac08c9ba7b6ac48d595cea0ab9

commit_message:
Fix display name change during backup restore

Currently the display name and description of the target volume
is changed to that in the backup meta-data during backup restore.
This can confuse the end-user, especially in the case of restore
to an existing volume. This patch removes display name and display
description from the list of fields to be copied from the backup
meta-data to update the volume.

Change-Id: I21a0505352ddc8db801f4820d575399a4771b259
Closes-Bug: #1376194
(cherry picked from commit 7ee80f76674bf4ee37b42a1223eb570138425ddd)

commit_message:
Adds a --json flag to request JSON output

Provides an alternative to prettytable output.
Also fixes a field in assembly logs command.

Closes-Bug: 1420437

Change-Id: I8b9283f94afed80c41f14fb1215317149857b3bc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-solumclient refs/changes/14/154614/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pprintfrom solumclient.openstack.common import cliutils json_output = False self.parser.add_argument('--json', action='store_true', help='JSON formatted output') args, _ = self.parser.parse_known_args() if args.json: self.json_output = True def _print_dict(self, dct, dict_property="Property", wrap=0): if self.json_output: pprint.pprint(dct, width=wrap) else: cliutils.print_dict(dct, dict_property, wrap) def _print_list(self, objs, fields, formatters=None, sortby_index=0, mixed_case_fields=None, field_labels=None): if self.json_output: subset = [dict([(f, vars(o).get(f, '')) for f in fields]) for o in objs] pprint.pprint(subset) else: cliutils.print_list(objs, fields, formatters, sortby_index, mixed_case_fields, field_labels)

commit_message:
Fix inconsistent sidebar toggle icon

The sidebar toggle icon is inconsistent in firefox and chrome,
the icon in chrome is bigger than which in firefox, we can see
the below screenshots:)

https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1425824/+attachment/4328067/+files/chrome.png
https://launchpadlibrarian.net/198780412/firefox.png

Change-Id: I195bef866cf215a2840a6d34690d3665822689fd
Closes-Bug: 1425824

commit_message:
VMware: prevent exception with migrate_disk_and_power_off

Commit 8e4a9156f4dccf003970848c28b8a9d15c55212d ensured that
all instance operations that do not require a cluster or
volume will make use of the base _vmops class.

The method migrate_disk_and_power_off was missed.

Change-Id: Ibfdd9407905acc5e9a3e3a97a76fb2e35a68e817
(cherry picked from commit eae20bb0064d1b03c400a464e2acff7561c68d41)

commit_message:
Updated OCF plugs network interfaces of namespaces
directly into bridges with bridge type autodetection

Change-Id: Ice193fed4bbd27d164edaebe8a959f8ce0e5d6a8
Blueprint: virtual-router-for-env-nodes
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/77/150777/34 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xOCF_RESKEY_gateway_default="" # can be "none", "link", IPaddrOCF_RESKEY_bridge_default="" # can be "", or bridge name: ${OCF_RESKEY_bridge=${OCF_RESKEY_bridge_default}}<parameter name="bridge"> <longdesc lang="en"> Name of the bridge that has ns_veth connected to it. </longdesc> <shortdesc lang="en">Name of the bridge.</shortdesc> <content type="string" default="$OCF_RESKEY_bridge"/> </parameter> add_to_bridge() { brctl show | grep $OCF_RESKEY_bridge if [[ $? == 0 ]]; then ocf_run brctl addif $OCF_RESKEY_bridge $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth && ocf_run ifconfig $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth 0.0.0.0 || return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC else ovs-vsctl show | grep $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth if [[ $? != 0 ]] ; then ocf_run ovs-vsctl add-port $OCF_RESKEY_bridge $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth -- set Interface $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth type=internal ocf_run ip link set $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth netns $OCF_RESKEY_ns fi fi return $OCF_SUCCESS } ovs-vsctl show | grep $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth if [[ $? != 0 ]] ; then ocf_run ip link add $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth type veth peer name $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth ocf_run ip link set dev $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth netns $OCF_RESKEY_ns ocf_run $RUN_IN_NS ip link set up dev $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth ocf_run ip link set up dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth sleep 1 fi if [[ -n $OCF_RESKEY_bridge ]] ; then ipaddr=`get_first_ip_mask_for_if $OCF_RESKEY_bridge` else ipaddr=`get_first_ip_mask_for_if $OCF_RESKEY_nic` fi ovs-vsctl show | grep $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth if [[ $? != 0 ]] ; then ocf_run ip addr add $ipaddr dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth fi if [[ -z $OCF_RESKEY_bridge ]] ; then echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/$OCF_RESKEY_nic/proxy_arp echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/$OCF_RESKEY_base_veth/proxy_arp else add_to_bridge fi fi ovs-vsctl show | grep $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth rc=$? if [[ $rc != 0 ]] ; then ocf_run ip route flush dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth [[ $? != 0 ]] && return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi if [[ -z $OCF_RESKEY_bridge ]] ; then ocf_run ip route add $OCF_RESKEY_ip dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth [[ $? != 0 ]] && return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi if [[ $OCF_RESKEY_gateway == 'link' ]] ; then ocf_run $RUN_IN_NS ip route replace default dev $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth metric $OCF_RESKEY_gateway_metric elif [[ $OCF_RESKEY_gateway == 'none' ]] ; then echo "Do nothing" else ocf_run $RUN_IN_NS ip route replace default via $OCF_RESKEY_gateway metric $OCF_RESKEY_gateway_metric local ns_iptables_rules if [[ ! -z $OCF_RESKEY_ns_iptables_start_rules ]] ; then IFS=';' read -a ns_iptables_rules <<< "$OCF_RESKEY_ns_iptables_start_rules" for rule in "${ns_iptables_rules[@]}" do ocf_run ip netns exec $OCF_RESKEY_ns $rule done fi local ns_iptables_rules if [[ ! -z $OCF_RESKEY_ns_iptables_stop_rules ]] ; then IFS=';' read -a ns_iptables_rules <<< "$OCF_RESKEY_ns_iptables_stop_rules" for rule in "${ns_iptables_rules[@]}" do ocf_run ip netns exec $OCF_RESKEY_ns $rule done fi if [[ -z $OCF_RESKEY_bridge ]] ; then local ipaddr=$(get_first_ip_for_if $OCF_RESKEY_bridge) else local ipaddr=$(get_first_ip_for_if $OCF_RESKEY_bridge) fi
deleted_lines: #!/bin/bashOCF_RESKEY_gateway_default="" # can be "", "link", IPaddr ocf_run ip link add $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth type veth peer name $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth ocf_run ip link set dev $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth netns $OCF_RESKEY_ns echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/$OCF_RESKEY_nic/proxy_arp echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/$OCF_RESKEY_base_veth/proxy_arp ocf_run $RUN_IN_NS ip link set up dev $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth ocf_run ip link set up dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth sleep 1 ipaddr=`get_first_ip_mask_for_if $OCF_RESKEY_nic` ocf_run ip addr add $ipaddr dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth fi ocf_run ip route flush dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth [[ $? != 0 ]] && return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC ocf_run ip route add $OCF_RESKEY_ip dev $OCF_RESKEY_base_veth [[ $? != 0 ]] && return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC if [[ ! -z $OCF_RESKEY_gateway ]] ; then if [[ $OCF_RESKEY_gateway == 'link' ]] ; then ocf_run $RUN_IN_NS ip route replace default dev $OCF_RESKEY_ns_veth metric $OCF_RESKEY_gateway_metric else ocf_run $RUN_IN_NS ip route replace default via $OCF_RESKEY_gateway metric $OCF_RESKEY_gateway_metric fi local ipaddr=$(get_first_ip_for_if $OCF_RESKEY_nic)

I noticed these telemetry classes were overloading repr.  The
reason they were doing this is they have to resource key or name,

Change-Id: I3a7090eb42fcc12f15d791172c2b63b3dbc85edf

commit_message:
Remove repr calls from telemetry classes

I noticed these telemetry classes were overloading repr.  The
reason they were doing this is they have to resource key or name,
but repr doesn't use that anymore.  We should use the base class
repr.

Change-Id: I3a7090eb42fcc12f15d791172c2b63b3dbc85edf

commit_message:
Add OSWL collector keystone user

Adds keystone user for gathering OpenStack
workload statistics. A separate user is needed
in case the administrator changes the default
user credentials. Further details about OSWL
collector in blueprint.

Change-Id: Idfc669b882c2c32a3805b36ffc58b27c58048e6d
blueprint openstack-workload-statistics

commit_message:
Fix removal of backup segments

When removing any object, freezer will check the object's metadata
to identify the presence of associated segments

This results in the correct removal of all parts of old backups

Change-Id: I03cedc47a581615b6a214ed9e32e99c0e6f91db9
Closes-Bug: #1429915

commit_message:
pass optional os_options on to switfclient library

Some os_options are optional but were not passed on
to the swiftclient library. More specifically they are:

  tenant_id
  tenant_name
  region_name

Change-Id: I3dff008368fc21ed0a9aa78ac555a3890eb86c34
Closes-Bug: #1427192

commit_message:
Main loop refactor

The code relative to the various actions is moved into their
respective job objects.
A factory function creates the correct type of job object according to
the action requested.
This replaces the long "if" chain in the main loop

The main loop calls the Job object's execute() method.

Change-Id: Iec1acfe62575ba062f9b56171784d1d74dc86556
Implements: blueprint freezer-main-refactor

commit_message:
Specs for neutron-agents-local-reports

blueprint neutron-agents-local-reports

Change-Id: If1fa249eec0b0f40fcfec6f242928610a338b3d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/96/144296/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Agent Local Reports ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/example Provide additional hints to local monitoring Problem description =================== Currently monitoring scripts make desicion about liveleness of neutron agents based on neutron server-list. In some cases it makes sense to detect other cases like inability to communicate with neutron server over message queue. In this case neutron agent-list command will show agent as dead, while it's not really so. So in order to provide additional hints to monitoring scripts 'local reports' are introduced. Local report is a piece of information written to a local file by neutron agent about status of certain kind of operations. Proposed change =============== Proposed change affects L3 and DHCP agents. Agents will write status of certain operations to a local file. The list of operations include: * startup * state reports status * network (for DHCP agent) or router (for L3 agent) synchronization with neutron server File will reside in the path, configured in neutron.conf as 'state path' The format of those report will include: * pid of the agent * time stamp of the status report * name of operation * status itself Currently preferred format is json. The reason for it is that json simplifies updating local reports file by reading-updating-writing its contents. This is needed so contents is not flushed/rewritten after agent restart. For ocf scripts that are bash-based it might be necessary to write additional script that will produce yaml-like output from that json, to simplify analysis via awk/grep. Main goal of local reports is help troubleshoot different issues that are not "visible" to methods like pid monitoring and "agent-list" Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- The change is not going to be submitted to upstream, so it must be kep it local repository for each release. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: enikanorov Other contributors: xenolog Work Items ---------- * state reports for L3 and DHCP agents * additional code for ocf monitoring that analyses local reports Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Testing should involve artificial interruption of rpc communication between agents and neutron server to test that ocf scripts can detect that through local reports file. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== 1. https://review.fuel-infra.org/#/c/1450/

subject: Cleaned up redundancy between instance update() and edit()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-03 01:21:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/b14ff244ffe7ab61c57c11f0f20f29433bee48e5', 'message': "Cleaned up redundancy between instance update() and edit().

The instance service.py was functionally redundant with respect
to 'configuration' functionality. This change modifed update()
to updater its body with appropriate configuration for edit(),
then delegate processing to edit().

No APIs were changed.

Tested using trove configuration-attach/detach and update with
--configuration and --remove-configuration CLIs.  Existing API
tests were deemed sufficient.

commit_message:
Cleaned up redundancy between instance update() and edit()

The instance service.py was functionally redundant with respect
to 'configuration' functionality. This change modifed update()
to update its body with appropriate configuration for edit(),
then delegate processing to edit().

No APIs were changed.

Tested using trove configuration-attach/detach and update with
--configuration and --remove-configuration CLIs.  Existing API
tests were deemed sufficient.

Modified the implementation to include a new method,
_modify_instance(), which is called by both update() and
edit().  In the previous implementation, update() called
edit() directly.

Added unit tests for _modify_instance().
Modified _modify_instance() unit tests per Eddie's comment.

This is a partial fix for bug 1364701.

Change-Id: Iaf198922ffbb4c4493309861902b1d16ffe739ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/91/160591/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Make sure instance in body contains a 'configuration' argument, # this is needed by edit() body['instance']['configuration'] = configuration_id return self.edit(req, id, body, tenant_id)
deleted_lines: instance = models.Instance.load(context, id) # If configuration is set, then we will update the instance to use the # new configuration. If configuration is empty, we want to disassociate # the instance from the configuration group and remove the active # overrides file. update_args = {} if configuration_id: instance.assign_configuration(configuration_id) else: instance.unassign_configuration() update_args['configuration_id'] = configuration_id instance.update_db(**update_args) return wsgi.Result(None, 202)

commit_message:
Remove shelve policy for nova compute layer

There are compute layer policy for shelve related
functions (shelve, unshelve, shelve_offload). However,
API layer already have the policy check and EC2
code do not have shelve policy. So keep the policy in the
compute layer doesn't make sense.

Prtially implements bp v3-api-policy
DocImpact

Change-Id: I2fd74bd58fc11d6afa5512a843e02a709e17124a

commit_message:
Add context.update_store in the _sync functions

Bug 1404268 states the need of update_store function in
green thread task functions. This patch is related to
that bug to fix similar issue.

Related-Bug: #1404268

Change-Id: Iadb33d99fef159028fff253fbbde4487dddab913

commit_message:
Give attachments time to stabilize on unrescue

There's been a long running issue observed in the
tempest test test_rescued_vm_detach_volume

The symptoms are detach/delete failures on the
cinder side due to timeouts or just extremely
long running LVM commands.  It turns out what
seems to be happening is that during rescue of
an instance with an attached volume, there's
a bit of swapping of devices on the compute node.

What happens is that during unrescue, we return
the instance back to ACTIVE however the device
paths haven't been updated properly, and as a
result when we try detach/delete of the volume in
our tempest tests LVM hangs waiting for an invalid
device to timeout.

This is mostly a temporary work-around until we
can figure out a better way to do this than a
dumb sleep.  We should be able to figure out
exactly what the state of the connections is
and how to monitor them until we know that
we're officially "done" with the unrescue.

Change-Id: Ib9f6b6569235d0ebd095a35e5f8566836d327793
DocImpact: update nova.conf docs
Closes-Bug: #1423654
Partial-Bug: #1373513

commit_message:
Fix delete a secret that does not exist

Changes the behavior of deleting a secret that does not exist.
The secret uuid is now verified as a valid UUID. If it not a valid
uuid it will result in a value error. A valid uuid will be allowed
to go through to the server and a 404 will be returned if the secret
does not exist.

Change-Id: I35e7fa36714604c2beba044d0e8bb492233bb7a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/76/162776/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_delete_doesnt_exist(self): """DELETE a non-existent secret.""" url = self.barbicanclient.secrets._api._base_url + '/secrets/notauuid' e = self.assertRaises(Exception, self.behaviors.delete_secret, url) self.assertEqual(e.message, 'Secret incorrectly specified.') @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_delete_doesnt_exist_valid_uuid_format(self): """DELETE a non-existent secret.""" uuid = 'de20ad54-85b4-421b-adb2-eb7b9e546013' url = self.barbicanclient.secrets._api._base_url + '/secrets/' + uuid e = self.assertRaises(Exception, self.behaviors.delete_secret, url) self.assertEqual(e.http_status, 404)

commit_message:
Support to move the horizon relative to web root

When deploying Horizon, on a web server, where other applications
are used, it's quite handy to be able to move Horizon around quickly.
This change introduces a single Variable WEBROOT to achieve this.

Implements: blueprint shared-webserver

Change-Id: Ic731f6754e233b328a8dbe7026b1d7417620fd66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/80/86880/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # WEBROOT is the locatoon relative to Apache Webserver root # should end with a slash. WEBROOT = '/' if not WEBROOT.endswith('/'): WEBROOT += '/' LOGIN_URL = WEBROOT + 'auth/login/' LOGOUT_URL = WEBROOT + 'auth/logout/'LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL = WEBROOT

commit_message:
Don't notify dead DHCP agent of removed networks

This is needed to avoid a case when agent sees network
removal notifications on startup. Processing of those notifications
may overlap with processing of active networks and DHCP might be
disabled on some of active networks as a result.

Change-Id: I8271e8fce8b4d80a339f598b98467694774a299e
Closes-Bug: #1429737

commit_message:
Prevent calling waitall() inside a GreenPool's greenthread

Keystone eventlet wsgi server is started in a green thread from
the same green pool that is passed to the server itself
to be used for spawning client green threads.

To avoid it, it is reasonable to use different pools for spawning
a wsgi server and for its internal usage.

Change-Id: I1246e2b730a522480ed495fbb53ae376ee7593d5
Closes-Bug: #1423250
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/20/160720/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, application, host=None, port=None, num_threads=1000, self.num_threads = num_threads # Pool for a green thread in which wsgi server will be running self.pool = eventlet.GreenPool(10) eventlet.wsgi.server(socket, application, max_size=self.num_threads,
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, application, host=None, port=None, threads=1000, self.pool = eventlet.GreenPool(threads) eventlet.wsgi.server(socket, application, custom_pool=self.pool,

commit_message:
test_neutron_resources slow tag to gate

commit_message:
Creating parameter to list inherited role assignments

This change adds the 'os_inherit_extension_inherited_to'
parameter when calling the list role assignment method.
It adds the following query to the URL:

http://host:35357/v3/role_assignments?scope.OS-INHERIT:inherited_to=projects

Co-Authored-By: Raildo Mascena <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: I9bfeecf4ae9da6a0d232f0cff80af64a16ec0829
Closes-bug: 1367868

added_lines: def test_role_assignments_inherited_list(self): ref_list = self.TEST_ALL_RESPONSE_LIST self.stub_entity('GET', [self.collection_key, '?role.id=' + self.TEST_ROLE_ID], entity=ref_list) returned_list = self.manager.list(role=self.TEST_ROLE_ID, inherited=True) self._assert_returned_list(ref_list, returned_list) kwargs = {'role.id': self.TEST_ROLE_ID, 'scope.OS-INHERIT:inherited_to': 'projects'} self.assertQueryStringContains(**kwargs) def test_effective_inherited_list(self): # Should only accept either effective or inherited, never both self.assertRaises(exceptions.ValidationError, self.manager.list, effective=True, inherited=True)

subject: libvirt: fix tracing and unicode handling in firewall._get_filter_uuid
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-10 16:21:43.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_firewall.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/firewall.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/62203f766759e1d58e8bd7e629841eb01981a151', 'message': "libvirt: fix tracing and unicode handling in firewall._get_filter_uuid

Commit 0f65a294d90d69fe6ad2047dc5f63ad362787926 fixed the
UnicodeEncodeError possibility in the debug message if the exception has
unicode in it, but introduced the usage of exc_info=True which is
dumping nearly 800K traces in normal gate runs since 3/3.

The better way to fix this bug is to keep the message the way it was
before the change that uses exc_info=True but cast the debug log message
argument as unicode.

An alternative is casting the exception variable with six.text_type, but
according to the oslo.i18n team the guideline is to make debug log
messages unicode if you're substituting in exception variables.

Adds a unit test to exhibit the bug and verify the change.

Closes-Bug: #1430383

Change-Id: I66d28c280ec6bc637d7363291ebc69fda9ca66d9
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: fix tracing and unicode handling in firewall._get_filter_uuid

Commit 0f65a294d90d69fe6ad2047dc5f63ad362787926 fixed the
UnicodeEncodeError possibility in the debug message if the exception has
unicode in it, but introduced the usage of exc_info=True which is
dumping nearly 800K traces in normal gate runs since 3/3.

The better way to fix this bug is to keep the message the way it was
before the change that uses exc_info=True but cast the debug log message
argument as unicode.

An alternative is casting the exception variable with six.text_type, but
according to the oslo.i18n team the guideline is to make debug log
messages unicode if you're substituting in exception variables.

Adds a unit test to exhibit the bug and verify the change.

Closes-Bug: #1430383

Change-Id: I66d28c280ec6bc637d7363291ebc69fda9ca66d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/163073/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except Exception as e: LOG.debug(u"Cannot find UUID for filter '%s': '%s'" % (name, e))
deleted_lines: except Exception: LOG.debug("Cannot find UUID for filter '%s'", name, exc_info=True)

commit_message:
Duplicate named AlarmDefinition for a specific TenantID

Code that checks for an already existing alarm name with the name sent through the patch method.
It will throw an exception if the name for the alarm definition that is requested to be patched
already exists for another alarmdefinition for that specific tenantid.

Change-Id: I1ec9dd8c0054e25b852f7f86e5fb88afc0dde766
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/01/157901/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: List<AlarmDefinition> alarmsDefinitions = returnAlarmDefinitionsForTenantID(tenantId); for (AlarmDefinition alarmDefinition : alarmsDefinitions) { if(alarmDefinition.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(name)){ throw new EntityExistsException( "An alarm definition with the same name already exists for project / tenant: %s named: %s", tenantId, name); } } /** * Returns the list of AlarmDefinitions for a tenantIDfor the {@code tenantID}. * * @throws EntityNotFoundException if the alarm cannot be found */ private List<AlarmDefinition> returnAlarmDefinitionsForTenantID(String tenantID) { List<AlarmDefinition> alarmDefinitions = repo.find(tenantID, null, null, null); return alarmDefinitions; }

subject: Increase flexibility with managing client keys in profile

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-03-03 17:44:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph/commit/465bab22e18f60040df55e5edd03c5031ecd44af', 'message': "Increase flexibility with managing client keys in profile

**This is just a draft for discussion**

I decided against creating a ceph::client class which would've
essentially been the same as ceph::profile::base and
ceph::profile::client combined with the support for any client
name and instead added this support built-in to ceph::profile::base.

There is a definite use case for a class that allows to install
and configure the base packages as well as set up a client key,
ex: an Openstack compute node with cinder volumes or a glance
controller node.

Backwards compatibility is maintained by keeping the previous way
of doing things but also provides a new, more flexible way of
setting up and injecting client keys.

Change-Id: Ie6adbd601388ab52c37037004bd0ceef9fc41942
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-03-05 23:15:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph/commit/429bac0bcf1e39bf04d3546baa4e125d26592651', 'message': 'Increase flexibility with managing client keys in profile

commit_message:
Increase flexibility with managing client keys in profile

This commit introduces the client_keys hash parameter to
ceph::profile. This allows one to use the profile to inject
and configure any client keys with any parameter.

Backwards compatibility is *NOT* maintained for the purpose
of staying as clean and as simple as possible in the context
of drafting the first stable release of puppet-ceph.
This avoids shipping the first stable release with, already,
a deprecation that will have to be maintained throughout an
entire release cycle.

Some tests have been added and test coverage is in general
improved as part of this commit.

Change-Id: Ie6adbd601388ab52c37037004bd0ceef9fc41942

added_lines: cinder_key = 'AQBleQdUmAzdFBAAlLVYKkiINFYhrizlxsY0cg==' '/etc/ceph/ceph.client.cinder.keyring' it 'should install one monitor and one client on one host based on hiera', :cephx do it 'should install one monitor with an extra custom client key and one client with a custom client key on one host', :cephx do hiera = <<-EOS ceph::profile::params::release: '#{release}' ceph::profile::params::authentication_type: 'cephx' ceph::profile::params::admin_key: '#{admin_key}' ceph::profile::params::mon_key: '#{mon_key}' EOS file = Tempfile.new('hieradata') begin file.write(hiera_shared + hiera) file.close rcp(:sp => file.path, :dp => hieradata_common, :d => node) ensure file.unlink end pp = <<-EOS include ::ceph::profile::mon ceph::key { 'client.cinder': secret => '#{cinder_key}', cap_mon => 'allow *', cap_osd => 'allow *', cap_mds => 'allow *', inject => true, inject_as_id => 'mon.', inject_keyring => '/var/lib/ceph/mon/ceph-first/keyring', } class { '::ceph::profile::client': client_name => 'client.cinder', client_key => '#{cinder_key}', client_key_mode => '0600' } EOS puppet_apply(pp) do |r| r.exit_code.should_not == 1 r.refresh r.exit_code.should_not == 1 end shell 'ceph -s' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /1 mons .* quorum 0 first/ r.stderr.should be_empty r.exit_code.should be_zero end shell 'ceph -n client.cinder -s' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /1 mons .* quorum 0 first/ r.stderr.should be_empty r.exit_code.should be_zero end shell 'ceph auth list' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /#{admin_key}/ r.exit_code.should be_zero end shell 'ceph auth list' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /#{cinder_key}/ r.exit_code.should be_zero end end it 'should uninstall one monitor' do puppet_apply(purge) do |r| r.exit_code.should_not == 1 end end it 'should install one monitor on first host, one client on second host based on hiera', :cephx do it 'should install one monitor on first host, one client with overriden parameters on the second host', :cephx do ['first', 'second'].each do |vm| hiera = <<-EOS ceph::profile::params::release: '#{release}' ceph::profile::params::authentication_type: 'cephx' ceph::profile::params::admin_key: '#{admin_key}' ceph::profile::params::mon_key: '#{mon_key}' EOS file = Tempfile.new('hieradata') begin file.write(hiera_shared + hiera) file.close rcp(:sp => file.path, :dp => hieradata_common, :d => node(:name => vm)) ensure file.unlink end if vm == "first" pp = <<-EOS include ::ceph::profile::mon ceph::key { 'client.cinder': secret => '#{cinder_key}', cap_mon => 'allow *', cap_osd => 'allow *', cap_mds => 'allow *', inject => true, inject_as_id => 'mon.', inject_keyring => '/var/lib/ceph/mon/ceph-first/keyring', } EOS end if vm == "second" pp = <<-EOS class { '::ceph::profile::client': client_name => 'client.cinder', client_key => '#{cinder_key}', client_key_mode => '0600' } EOS end puppet_apply(:node => vm, :code => pp) do |r| r.exit_code.should_not == 1 r.refresh r.exit_code.should_not == 1 end end ['first', 'second'].each do |vm| if vm == "first" shell 'ceph -s' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /1 mons .* quorum 0 first/ r.stderr.should be_empty r.exit_code.should be_zero end shell 'ceph auth list' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /#{admin_key}/ r.exit_code.should be_zero end shell 'ceph auth list' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /#{cinder_key}/ r.exit_code.should be_zero end end if vm == "second" shell 'ceph -n client.cinder -s' do |r| r.stdout.should =~ /1 mons .* quorum 0 first/ r.stderr.should be_empty r.exit_code.should be_zero end end end end it 'should uninstall one monitor' do [ 'second', 'first' ].each do |vm| puppet_apply(:node => vm, :code => purge) do |r| r.exit_code.should_not == 1 end end end

commit_message:
Remove unused checkout_vendor

Keystone tests don't, and shouldn't, use checkout_vendor, so
remove it and other test functions that it was calling and are
now unused.

Change-Id: I530560d2b7e57278116fab6a4f7df3ea61e757c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/83/162483/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Additional test coverage for password changes

Keystone has four API calls which may result in a user's password
changing.

1. Administrative password reset on v2:

    POST /v2.0/users/{user_id}/OS-KSADM/password

2. Self-service password change on v2:

    PATCH /v2.0/OS-KSCRUD/users/{user_id}

3. Administrative password reset on v3:

    POST /v3/users/{user_id}

4. Self-service password change on v3:

    POST /v3/users/{user_id}/password

This patch adds additional test coverage to *consistently* ensure that:

- Old passwords no longer work
- Old tokens no longer work
- The new password works

Change-Id: I2a296b7ed407c75018fff3b60bd13aaa4fa9a849
Closes-Bug: 1407105
(cherry picked from commit a22aa08bf2176ac2da75258223f58d70303259e4)

commit_message:
Fix seconds since epoch use in fernet tokens

The fernet code wasn't using seconds since the epoch correctly.
The seconds since epoch doesn't depend on the timezone, but the
time int calculated by the fernet functions was based on the local
time of the system.

This was causing local unit tests to fail.

Closes-Bug: 1429663
Change-Id: I56757e9636e7baf46eeb1657dab209616e310672

commit_message:
Add Python 3.4 as supported interpreters

Rally code is python 3.4 compatible(required several small fixes, see a list
below for more details), so we can mention this great information in
setup.cfg file.

Fixed py34 incompatibe issues:
 - usage of OrderedDict for storing task results. Order of such results as
AtomicActions is important.
 - printed sla results are sorted by criterea name, so the results are equal
in all envs

commit_message:
Add warning for 2 compute periodic checks

2bfc7171c23d0595aa7f8680271778bc58cb28ba
Add warning to periodic_task with interval 0
added some check for deprecating in Icehouse and
in Juno 324d951667aa973955cebd6e49d98af6f2aba916
removed those warning and make the change.

_heal_instance_info_cache and _poll_volume_usage
are missing during previous patch, so this patch
adds it.

oslo already checked _periodic_spacing if
it's < 0, then the periodic task is disabled
it's = 0, then the periodic task spacing is default (60)
so no need to check it in nova manager.

Those check will be warned at Kilo and removed at L release.

Change-Id: I12d55b600dc1fda38cc7b7405f57d8dd91ee3d38
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/137009/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Change request for discussion on default template implementation

This simple CR has been created for feedback on implementation
details for default templates. It is not meant to merge.
Please add thoughts to comments. There will be a thread
on [openstack-dev][sahara] as well. Once we have some
kind of consensus we can modify the existing spec and
add more detail.

Two primary questions at this point, see comments for
more detail.

* Should this separate CLI for default-templates tie in
to Sahara at the conductor level, or the db api level?

* Do we want/need the CLI to authenticate to keystone,
or do we just create necessary elements of a context
manually?

Change-Id: I1bb18ab74616f1f1ec78e6b1c791d2a302dd0e0d
Partial-implements: blueprint default-templates
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/72/159872/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sahara-templates = sahara.db.templates.cli:main

commit_message:
First set of negative secrets tests.

Adds 3 negative secret tests. Also fixes an issue where calling
store on a secret with a payload set to None would cause an error
when trying to parse None for the URL.

Change-Id: If19755dbaa83abd0d431133f9b6662aa566ef483
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/42/161442/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_create_nones_content_type(self): """Create secret with valid content type but no payload. This test should fail """ test_model = self.behaviors.create_secret( secret_create_defaults_data) test_model.payload = None e = self.assertRaises(ValueError, self.behaviors.store_secret, test_model) self.assertEqual("Payload cannot be None.", e.message) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_create_nones(self): """Cover case of posting with all nones in the Secret object. This test is positive in the API but will return negative in the client due to the client requiring a payload. """ test_model = self.behaviors.create_secret( secret_create_nones_data) test_model.payload = None test_model.payload_content_encoding = None test_model.payload_content_type = None e = self.assertRaises(ValueError, self.behaviors.store_secret, test_model) self.assertEqual('Payload cannot be None.', e.message) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_get_secret_doesnt_exist(self): """GET a non-existent secret. commit_message:
Second set of negative functional tests for secrets

This set of tests addresses a bug that causes a failure when
retrieving a secret that is not valid. If you provide a url with
an incorrectly formated UUID a proper message is displayed.
If you provide a correctly formated uuid that is not a valid secret
or the secret is expired it returns a secret object with errors
for each object saying attribute is not defined.

Change-Id: I45fa72f7ec37b3469f80c5593eba8335ae5db6e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/46/161846/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_get_secret_doesnt_exist_valid_uuid_format(self): """GET an invalid secret ref with valid uuid format. """ uuid = 'de20ad54-85b4-421b-adb2-eb7b9e546013' url = self.barbicanclient.secrets._api._base_url + '/secrets/' + uuid secret = self.behaviors.get_secret(url) #e = self.assertRaises(Exception, self.behaviors.get_secret, # url) self.assertIn("Secret incorrectly specified", e.message) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_secret_create_defaults_then_expire_then_check(self): """Covers case where you try to retrieve a secret that is expired. This test creates a secret that will soon expire. After it expires, check it and verify that it is no longer a valid secret. """ # create a secret that expires in 5 seconds timestamp = utils.create_timestamp_w_tz_and_offset(seconds=5) test_model = self.behaviors.create_secret( secret_create_defaults_data) test_model.expiration = timestamp secret_ref = self.behaviors.store_secret(test_model) self.assertIsNotNone(secret_ref) # now get the secret - will be still valid get_resp = self.behaviors.get_secret(secret_ref) self.assertEqual(get_resp.name, test_model.name) # now wait 10 seconds time.sleep(10) # now get the secret - should be invalid (expired) resp = self.behaviors.get_secret(secret_ref) self.assertIn(resp, 404)

commit_message:
Fix zuul log path again

In I97362b1cc6a8c19b54903e53638aba8cb4928e19 an extra '/' was removed
from most instances of BASE_LOG_PATH, except for ones generated for
changes in periodic pipelines.  Add the missing '/' in that case.

Change-Id: Ibd99b88651d5cc3a7627fd4843a9a24f9be68464

commit_message:

added_lines: import resourceimport subprocessfrom six.moves import range as compat_rangedef _yield_fds(streams): for s in streams: if isinstance(s, int): yield s else: try: yield s.fileno() except AttributeError: # Someone is *likely* unit testing and is mocking out # these, leave it alone then... pass def __init__(self): """Constructor.""" def _close_descriptors(self): # Close file-descriptors (for safety purposes) except the instance # pipes (and the standard ones); sharing them with the parent is # typically bad and a general source of errors. max_fds = resource.getrlimit(resource.RLIMIT_NOFILE)[1] if max_fds == resource.RLIM_INFINITY: max_fds = subprocess.MAXFD try: sc_fds = os.sysconf("SC_OPEN_MAX") if sc_fds != -1 and sc_fds < max_fds: max_fds = sc_fds except OSError: pass exclude_fds = sorted(set(_yield_fds([self.readpipe, self.writepipe]))) LOG.debug('Closing all descriptors except %s (and the standard' ' descriptors) [fd upper bound is %s)]', exclude_fds, max_fds) first = None for fd in compat_range(3, max_fds): if fd in exclude_fds: if first is not None: os.closerange(first, fd) first = None continue if first is None: first = fd if first is not None: os.closerange(first, fd + 1) def _child_process(self, service): self._close_descriptors() # Block while any of child processes have exited pid, status = os.waitpid(0, 0)
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, wait_interval=0.01): """Constructor. :param wait_interval: The interval to sleep for between checks of child process exit. """ self.wait_interval = wait_interval def _child_process(self, service): # Don't block if no child processes have exited pid, status = os.waitpid(0, os.WNOHANG) # Yield to other threads if no children have exited # Sleep for a short time to avoid excessive CPU usage # (see bug #1095346) eventlet.greenthread.sleep(self.wait_interval)

commit_message:
Keep localrc.rc in sync with devstack

Updates the script to do a replace of the section in localrc from
the redstack localrc.rc. This allows you to add to the devstack
localrc or change the localrc in redstack and it will keep them
in sync.

Change-Id: I97f967ed572b916fc89688a255cc7888660d00e6
Closes-Bug: 1370946

commit_message:
default pecan debug to false

pecan outputs extremely verbose details when debug is set. right
or wrong, operators tend to use debug in production. this patch
minimise security impact of arguably bad deployment choices.

Change-Id: I69cf0befdf4acb5ddeac01cfda640ee6f86c4f38
Closes-Bug: #1425206
