commit_message:
Bare Metal Trust Using Intel TXT

This provides a trust boot solution, to determine the node
is trusted or not after deployed with Ironic, leveraging
Intel TXT to measure BIOS, Option ROM and Kernel/Ramdisk.
Talk and Demo:
https://www.openstack.org/summit/openstack-paris-summit-2014/
session-videos/presentation/trusted-bare-metal-what-and-39-s-that
Co-Authored-By: Bhandaru, Malini K <malini.k.bhandaru@intel.com>
Change-Id: I046030cc42f943435ec6fc078c31228c1b22bd99

Change-Id: I09349884a9912eb8d1384973ed91b464570ecde5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/35/162835/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Bare Metal Trust Using Intel TXT ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/bare-metal-trust-using-intel-txt This blueprint uses Intel TXT[6], which builds a chain of trust rooted in special purpose hardware and measures the BIOS, boot loader, Option ROM and the Kernel/Ramdisk, to determine whether a bare metal node deployed by Ironic may be trusted. Problem description =================== While hypervisors and virtual machines are a common paradigm in the Cloud, heavy compute users seek Bare Metal (BM) to eliminate the performance overhead incurred by virtualization. How can the user be confident that the BM node obtained is free of malware? How can the cloud provider determine that an user released BM is free of malware, after all a BM user has full access to the machine and could have introduced rootkits and other malware. There are two typical use cases for trusted boot: 1. Admin want to determine that an user released BM node is free of malware. Admin run a CLEANING task, booting a customize image on the node with trusted boot which will validate the integrity of firmware. Ironic will poll the reuslt from an additional service. If it is trusted, go to available state. Otherwise, run a zapping task to flash firmware. 2. User want to be confident that the BM node obtained is free of malware. Ironic run a DEPLOYING task with trusted boot, that's all for Ironic. User can check the result after login in OS. Proposed solution: ------------------- Our solution essentially mimics how one may download software and compute its MD5 hash and compare against its advertised MD5 hash to determine its legitimacy. It involves using Intel TXT, which is comprises hardware, software, and firmware. The hardware, attached to the platform, called the Trusted Platform Module (TPM)[5], provides the hardware root of trust. Firmware on the same is used to compute secure hashes and save the same to a set of registers called Platform Configuration Registers (PCRs), with different registers containing different measurements. Other components are Intel virtualization technology, signed code modules, and a trusted boot loader called TBOOT[1]. Essentially the BIOS, option ROM, and kernel/Ramdisk are all measured into the various PCRs. From a bare metal trust standpoint, we are interested in PCRs 0-7(BIOS, option ROM). The kernel/Ramdisk measurements would depend on the image the tenant seeks to launch on their bare metal instance. PCR value testing is provided by an open attestation service, OAT[2]. Additional details in references. We integrate Ironic with Intel TXT to enable detection on boot of any changes in the BIOS, PCIe device firmware, and/or kernel/Ramdisk from expected values. The bare metal is trusted only when there is an exact match. On a legitimate update, for example BIOS firmware upgrade, it is necessary to update the whitelist to include the new expected measurements. For increased cloud security, it is good practice to maintain the whitelist, clearing out old values after all machines are upgraded/updated. Result: An OAT client in the customize image verify the trust state and pass the value to Ironic. The related Horizon blueprint [12] addresses displaying the trust status of a bare metal node on boot. An administrator on introducing new hardware into the cloud can confirm whether they need to update the whitelist if on boot the machine fails attestation. This could happen for any of many reasons, such as new hardware distinct from existing machines in the data center/enterprise, a BIOS upgrade, new PCIe device attachments etc. Further, during the registration/enrollment phase of the machine, the cloud admin will update the "node.properties" field in the database to include "intel-txt-enabled : true". Limitations and Future Work: ---------------------------- 1) Hot Add/Remove of PCIe devices are not supported. A machine reboot is necessary to obtain fresh measurements and re-attestation. 2) On detecting that a bare metal instance does not meet trust measurements, we shall log it. In the future, we shall introduce a Ceilometer alert event to be consumed by the cloud administrator, perhaps need follow-up with prior tenant. Additionally there is a cleaning step like BP[4] that will address reflashing BIOS and Option ROMS. Till reflash, the untrusted bare metal node will not allocated to any tenant. 3) To increase cloud security, after a tenant releases a bare metal node, it is good to confirm that it remains trusted. In particular are its PCRs 0-7 as expected. This attestation test could be added to the workflow where nodes are cleaning on release. Should it fail, see (2). 4) Blue Pill The hardware virtualization support is enabled without a hypervisor running, the machine is open to launch a Blue Pill style attack. Unfortunately OEM vendors do not provide the capability to disable Intel TXT or its equivalents and those that tried to support the same insisted on establishing physical presence. The reasoning here is the dynamic control feature itself could pose a vulnerability. Our goal is unaffected by the Blue Pill aspect because we are concerned strictly with establishing that a machine prior to hand-off to a tenant is clean, free of rootkits and malware. Should the tenant seek to install a rootkit, that is in their purview. Once the machine is released back to the cloud, our workflow will detect and erase the same. This said, no claims of trust or re-attestation of a bare metal machine are possible post boot time. In the Horizon dashboard re-attest action will not be provided. Node boot time and trust status at boot time will be displayed. Workflow -------- From node enrollment to allocation and release, the various steps. Note BIOS re-flash and enable TXT will not be available in Kilo but there is community momentum to build in the feature, thus expected soon. 1. Zapping task (enable TXT, VT-x, VT-d, take ownership of TPM) (register in Ironic DB node.properties intel-txt-enabled == true) 2. Cleaning task (Boot a customize image with OAT-Client in trusted boot) (Passing OAT server url for attestation) 3. Attestation (Outside of Ironic) Node sends its PCR values to OAT-Server for attestation PCRs(0-7) BIOS/Option ROM related PCRs(17-22) kernel/Ramdisk related For bare metal trust we are chiefly concerned with PCRs(0-7) 4. Ironic poll the reuslt from OAT-Server as part of clean task if trusted: Nodes are available and Jump to 6 5. Zapping task Reflash Node // false 6. Deploying Boot guest image in trusted boot 7. Attestation by user (optional) 8. Tenant releases node 9. Jump to 2 The solution includes two parts, measure and verify: 1.0 MEASURE 1.1 Enable TXT in BIOS(Workflow step 1) This is a prerequisite. We need at least three reboots to enable TPM and TXT. This should be done manually for now, as it is OEM vendor-specific. Future plan is working as Zapping task. Some scripts may also be available at a later date to handle this aspect for some OEMs/hardware vendors. 1.2. Using Trust Boot mode to measure.(Workflow step 2 and 6) Leverage TBOOT to generate PCRs values during trusted boot. Platform Configuration Registers (PCRs) are protected registers provided by TPM to store measurement. 2.0 VERIFY (Workflow step 3 and 7) 2.1 Inject OAT-Client into image Create a customize image with OAT-Client installed. OpenAttestation (OAT) is a Remote Attestation solution. It includes several OAT-Clients and one OAT-Server. OAT-Client should be installed on each bare metal node to interact with TPM. OAT-Server has a whitelist to verify the PCRs values from OAT-Client. 2.2 Register Node into OAT-Server to verify. This action happens when nodes become active. In order to securely pass PCRs values to OAT-Server, OAT-Client has to download OAT-Server's certifications and register itself into OAT-Server's DB. Pass OAT-Server IP address to Node to configure OAT-Client and start service, Node call OAT-Server to compare PCR values from TPM with whitelist in OAT-Server. Proposed change =============== Add a new PXE boot mode, trusted boot: * Read value "trusted_boot" from flavor pass boolean value "trusted_boot" to switch_pxe_config() switch to "trusted_boot" section. * Modify PXE configuration Add a new section "trusted_boot". It will make use of mboot.c32 which supports multiple loading. It loads TBOOT first. TBOOT will measure Kernel/Ramdisk before loading them. PXE config template: label trusted_boot kernel mboot append tboot.gz --- {{pxe_options.aki_path}} root={{ ROOT }} ro text {{ pxe_options.pxe_append_params|default("", true) }} intel_iommu=on --- {{pxe_options.ari_path}} * Modify iPXE configuration: As ipxe doesn't support multiple loading and pxelinux supports HTTP/FTP/TFTP, we choose to load pxelinux.0 and use pxe_config.template again. By default, pxelinux will look for its configuration file using TFTP. We need to specify DHCP options 209/210 in trusted_boot.ipxe #209 = pxelinux config path #210 = pxelinux root set 210:string http://$myip:port/ set 209:string http://$myip:port/pxelinux.cfg/${mac:hexraw} chain http://$myip:port/pxelinux.0 ipxe config example: label trusted_boot kernel mboot append tboot.gz --- http://10.239.48.36:8081/ff2b0eb9-7fa8-4745-8caa-ee757d72410f/kernel root=UUID=2d2d2d75-48ce-4530-9bd1-790f2b357b1e ro text nofb nomodeset vga=normal intel_iommu=on --- http://10.239.48.36:8081/ff2b0eb9-7fa8-4745-8caa-ee757d72410f/ramdisk Add a clean task validate the integrity of firmware: * Boot a customize image on release nodes with trust boot. * Poll the result from OAT-Server Alternatives ------------ Secure Boot in BP[11]. The main difference is secure boot will verify the sign before execute and trusted boot will execute and measure&verify. They can complement each other to a security cloud. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ Will pass the extra_spec "trusted_boot" to Ironic depends on 'pass-flavor-capabilities-to-ironic-virt-driver.rst'. Security impact --------------- Increase confidence in bare metal nodes being free of rootkits and other malware Intel TXT and TPM are available and leveraged. Other end user impact --------------------- Increased confidence that their bare metal nodes are free of malware. Scalability impact ------------------ According to our experiments, Concurrent requests with 5 clients need 1.7s, 10 clients need 2.3s, 16 clients need 3.3s to obtain the trust status from oat-server. This is only for poll/wait. Performance Impact ------------------ According to our experiments, It needs an additional 10 seconds to run oat-client related service and get trust status when nodes become active. This includes oat-client initialize and poll/wait. Other deployer impact --------------------- * A special flavor with 'trusted_boot=True' * Additionally two items need to be provided with tftpboot/httpboot folder "mboot.c32" - Support multiple loading from /usr/lib/syslinux/mboot.c32 "tboot.gz" - a pre-kernel module to do measurement. * OAT-Server needs to be started up and the whitelist therein provisioned with expected values. OEM provided BIOS and Option ROM hashes can be used to determine expected PCRs 0-7 values for the various hardware. * When hardware is registered in the cloud/data center, a few additional one time manual steps are required. These involve enabling in the BIOS Intel TXT, VT-x, and VT-d, and taking ownership of the TPM. * Create images with OAT-Client. Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tan-lin-good Work Items ---------- * Add trusted_boot section to pxe_config.template * Add trusted_boot.ipxe * Support trusted_boot flag and switch to trusted_boot. Dependencies ============ * TBOOT * OAT * Hardware Support: TPM and Intel TXT Testing ======= Will add Unit Testing. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Backwards compatibility is achieved by not requesting "trusted" bare metal. Custom tenant images are accomodated by deploying an initial standard image that has the OAT client embedded. Today Fedora releases come bundled with the OAT client. This solution approach, while increasing the number of boots preserves us from having to doctor the tenant image by way of injecting the OAT client into the same, or requiring that bare metal users provide images with an OAT client included. Documentation Impact ==================== Will document usage and benefits. References ========== 1. http://sourceforge.net/projects/tboot/ 2. https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation 3. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/133828/ 4. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102685/ 5. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Platform_Module 6. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Execution_Technology 7. http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/architecture-and-technology/trusted-execution-technology/malware-reduction-general-technology.html 8. http://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/white-papers/trusted-execution-technology-security-paper.pdf 9. http://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/guides/intel-txt-software-development-guide.pdf 10. http://www.apress.com/9781430261483 A Guide to More Secure Datacenters 11. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/135845/ 12. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/bare-metal-trust-status 13. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Pill_%28software%29 14. http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/content/trusted-compute-pools.html

commit_message:
Add functional testing README

Outline the background and goal of the functional testing.  Want to make
sure there is consensus on how this should look. Next step is to
reorganize the functional tests to follow the plan outlined here.

Change-Id: I1d6889682f50f78b0681c99b77475adba95ef807
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/34/162334/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================================== python-novaclient functional testing ===================================== Idea ------ Over time we have noticed two issues with novaclient unit tests. * Does not exercise the CLI * We can get the expected server behavior wrong, and test the wrong thing. We are using functional tests, run against a running cloud (primarily devstack), to address these two cases. Additionally these functional tests can be considered example uses of python-novaclient. These tests started out in tempest as read only nova CLI tests, to make sure the CLI didn't simply stacktrace when being used (which happened on multiple occasions). Testing Theory ---------------- We are treating python-novaclient as legacy code, so we do not want to spend a lot of effort adding in missing features. In the future the CLI will move to python-openstackclient, and the python API will be based on the OpenStack SDK project. But unitl that happens we still need better functional testing, to prevent regressions etc. Since python-novaclient has two uses, CLI and python API, we should have two sets of functional tests. CLI and python API. The python API tests should never use the CLI. But the CLI tests can use the python API where adding native support to the CLI for the required functionality would involve a non trivial amount of work. Functional Test Guidelines --------------------------- * Consume credentials via standard client environmental variables * Try not to require an addition configuration file

commit_message:
Failed to load xml configure file

Change in huawei_helper.py. Use the following method to load
the file failed, Because in Python27 that 'module' object has
no attribute 'ElementTree'.
from xml.etree import ElementTree as ET
tree = ET.parse(filename)

Change-Id: Iaaecfaba9cebec24e1786ba74681cf7bb4630b9b
Closes-Bug: #1428564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/98/161998/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from xml.etree import ElementTree as ET tree = ET.parse(filename) tree = ET.parse(filename)
deleted_lines: from xml import etree tree = etree.ElementTree.parse(filename) tree = etree.ElementTree.parse(filename)

commit_message:
Just to delete the stack when adopt rollback

If stack adopt failed and need to rollback, we just
enter the abandon flow only to delete the stack.

Change-Id: Ia7f9915fa40e8e836a41c0b9cc9b8051ae2e0d23
Closes-Bug: #1408904
(cherry picked from commit 4af2892fbbf730827c1237ab169e681bab506515)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/46/161146/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # enter the same flow as abandon and just delete the stack for res in self.resources.values(): res.abandon_in_progress = True self.delete(action=self.ROLLBACK, abandon=True)

commit_message:
Add support to incremental backups in cinder

1. Added a new option to create backup to support incremental backups.
   New CLI option added for "cinder backup": --incremental or --incr
   By default, it is full backup.
   Add the following to API: 'incremental': True or False
   (False is the default)
2. swift.py creates sha256file for every backup to calculate deltas

DocImpact
APIImpact
Co-Authored-By: Xing Yang <xing.yang@emc.com>
Implements: blueprint incremental-backup
Change-Id: I98f3765f7afa47bda6a8c7004f809c3cc4d1bd4b

commit_message:
Release stack lock when successfully acquire

Should not to release the stack lock if acquire failed,
such as stack action in progress.

Change-Id: I2a519c47306065b0a3412a8c6faa64006dea691f
Closes-Bug: #1418360
(cherry picked from commit 00c599319577730fcd085d9645fbe14a7f61c4ee)

Nova should unbind the port from the instance on delete if the port was not created by Nova as part of the boot request. """ # Setup the network, create a port and boot the server from that port. self._setup_network_and_servers(boot_with_port=True) _, server = self.floating_ip_tuple self.assertIsNotNone(self.port_id, 'Server should have been created from a ' 'pre-existing port.') LOG.info('>>>> #1 : _list_ports : %r', self._list_ports(device_id=server['id'])) LOG.info('>>>> #2 : _list_ports : %r', self._list_ports(device_id=server['id'], network_id=self.network['id'])) LOG.info('>>>> #3 : _list_ports : %r', self._list_ports(network_id=self.network['id'], device_id='', device_owner='')) # Assert the port is bound to the server. port_list = self._list_ports(device_id=server['id'], network_id=self.network['id']) self.assertEqual(1, len(port_list), 'There should only be one port created for ' 'server %s.' % server['id']) self.assertEqual(self.port_id, port_list[0]['id']) # Delete the server. self.servers_client.delete_server(server['id']) self.servers_client.wait_for_server_termination(server['id']) LOG.info('>>>> #4 : _list_ports : %r', self._list_ports(device_id=server['id'])) LOG.info('>>>> #5 : _list_ports : %r', self._list_ports(device_id=server['id'], network_id=self.network['id'])) LOG.info('>>>> #6 : _list_ports : %r', self._list_ports(network_id=self.network['id'], device_id='', device_owner='')) # Assert the port still exists on the network but is unbound from # the deleted server. port_list = self._list_ports(network_id=self.network['id'], device_id='', device_owner='') self.assertEqual(1, len(port_list), 'After server delete, pre-existing port %s should ' 'still be on network %s' % (self.port_id, self.network['id'])) port = port_list[0] self.assertEqual(self.port_id, port['id'])

commit_message:
WIP: partially fix the bug of live-migration with config drive

In current version of nova, live-migration with config drive on
local disk is forbbiden due to the bug of libvirt of copying readonly
disk.

However, if we use vfat as the format of config drive,
the function of live-migration works well.

In this patch, we re-open the function of live-migration to admin users.
Notice you should add 'config_drive_format = vfat' in nova.conf explicitly.

This patch doesn't solve the problem fundamentally which need further
efforts, but offers a simple and feasible solution to user.

Change-Id: Iee7c27d690b4a2513bbe563faa6c7b34f290b942
Partial-Bug: #1246201

commit_message:
Fix param description on _make_request

make_requests requires a list of headers but _make_request needs
just headers dictionary (not a list).

Change-Id: Iaf7ba32de3702bf2189f41e42041b561c9d1b57b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/92/162592/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: :param headers: a list of dicts, where each dict represents one backend request that should be made.

subject: SemVer utility to store object versions in DB
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-17 12:48:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/bbfdf3aed899ed8d1bb20c1759279eb0c7a47884', 'message': "SemVer utility to operate on object versions in SemVer notation

Introduce a Version class to store artifacts' versions as a combination of
Major, Minor and Patch with optional pre-release label and build metadata.
All according to SemVer spec (www.semver.org).

Contains functions to convert version components into a long integer
(64 bit value) which may be used to order a set of version data by comparing
values of a single field, which may be useful when the data is persisted in DB

Needed for Artifacts model

Change-Id: I33212ea92cca50a143b9141f8147f7db27bb9e7c

"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2014-10-30 17:53:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/7a0ce38126d40704bb68fb9301e41ee1d5191273', 'message': "SemVer utility to operate on object versions in SemVer notation

Introduce a Version class to store artifacts' versions as a combination of
Major, Minor and Patch with optional pre-release label and build metadata.
All according to SemVer spec (www.semver.org).

Contains functions to convert version components into a long integer
(64 bit value) which may be used to order a set of version data by comparing
values of a single field, which may be useful when the data is persisted in DB

library) into a combination of long 64-bit integer value and two preformatted
strings. If stored in the database these values unambiguously define object
precedence according to semver notation. This may be used for correct ordering

use it directly in SQLAlchemy object models to define version fields and query
the database.

commit_message:
SemVer utility to store object versions in DB

Adds an utility which may convert Version objects (provided by
semantic_version library) into a combination of long 64-bit integer
value and two preformatted strings. If stored in the database these
values unambiguously define object precedence according to semver
notation. This may be used for correct ordering of database queries.

Adds a class which is compatible with SQLAlchemy composite field, so one
may use it directly in SQLAlchemy object models to define version fields
and query the database.

Needed for Artifacts model

Depends-on: I74c00625634f246a96a1a9db4e6ff4335e649404

Implements-blueprint: semver-support

Change-Id: I33212ea92cca50a143b9141f8147f7db27bb9e7c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/76/107676/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from glance.common import exception from glance.common import semver from glance.tests import utils as test_utils class SemVerTestCase(test_utils.BaseTestCase): def test_version_detailed_create(self): v = semver.Version(1, 2, 3, 'beta', '07.17.2014') self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(2, v.minor) self.assertEquals(3, v.patch) self.assertTrue(v.is_prerelease()) self.assertEquals('beta', v.label) self.assertEquals('07.17.2014', v.meta) def test_version_minimal_create(self): v = semver.Version(10) self.assertEquals(10, v.major) self.assertEquals(0, v.minor) self.assertEquals(0, v.patch) self.assertIsNone(v.label) self.assertIsNone(v.meta) self.assertFalse(v.is_prerelease()) def test_version_repr(self): v = semver.Version(1, 2, 3, 'beta', '07.17.2014') self.assertEquals('1.2.3-beta+07.17.2014', str(v)) def test_version_parse_label_meta(self): s = '1.2.3-beta+07.17.2014' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(2, v.minor) self.assertEquals(3, v.patch) self.assertEquals('beta', v.label) self.assertTrue(v.is_prerelease()) self.assertEquals('07.17.2014', v.meta) def test_version_parse_label(self): s = '1.2.3-beta' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(2, v.minor) self.assertEquals(3, v.patch) self.assertEquals('beta', v.label) self.assertTrue(v.is_prerelease()) self.assertIsNone(v.meta) def test_version_parse_meta(self): s = '1.2.3+07.17.2014' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(2, v.minor) self.assertEquals(3, v.patch) self.assertIsNone(v.label) self.assertFalse(v.is_prerelease()) self.assertEquals('07.17.2014', v.meta) def test_version_parse_simple(self): s = '1.2.3' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(2, v.minor) self.assertEquals(3, v.patch) self.assertIsNone(v.label) self.assertIsNone(v.meta) self.assertFalse(v.is_prerelease()) def test_parse_major_minor_w_label(self): s = '1.2-rc1' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(2, v.minor) self.assertEquals(0, v.patch) self.assertEquals('rc1', v.label) self.assertIsNone(v.meta) self.assertTrue(v.is_prerelease()) def test_parse_label_with_dashes(self): s = '1.2.3-alpha-beta-gamma' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals('alpha-beta-gamma', v.label) def test_parse_meta_with_dashes(self): s = '1.2.3+17-jun-2014' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals('17-jun-2014', v.meta) def test_parse_major_only_w_meta(self): s = '1+123' v = semver.parse(s) self.assertEquals(1, v.major) self.assertEquals(0, v.minor) self.assertEquals(0, v.patch) self.assertIsNone(v.label) self.assertEquals('123', v.meta) self.assertFalse(v.is_prerelease()) def test_incorrect_parsing(self): self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, semver.parse, '1.2.3.4') self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, semver.parse, '1.2.a') self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, semver.parse, '1.2.3+meta1+meta2') def test_label_w_leading_zero(self): self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, semver.parse, '1.2.3-004') def test_major_comparison(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 1, 100) v2 = semver.Version(2, 0, 0) self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_minor_comparison(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 1, 10) v2 = semver.Version(1, 2, 1) self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_patch_comparison(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 1, 1) v2 = semver.Version(1, 1, 100) self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_label_comparison(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'alpha') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0) self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_label_comparison_alphas(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'alpha') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'beta') self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_label_comparison_numeric(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'alpha.1') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'alpha.2') self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_label_comparison_alpha_numeric(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, '100') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'alpha') self.assertGreater(v2, v1) def test_equals(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0) v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0) self.assertEqual(v1, v2) def test_equals_w_different_meta(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, meta='someMeta') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, meta='otherMeta') self.assertEqual(v1, v2) def test_not_equal_w_different_labels(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, label='rc1', meta='someMeta') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, label='rc2', meta='someMeta') self.assertNotEqual(v1, v2) def test_long_conversion(self): v = semver.Version(1, 2, 3, 'beta', '07.17.2014') l = v.as_long() v2 = semver.from_long(l, v.label, v.meta) self.assertEquals(1, v2.major) self.assertEquals(2, v2.minor) self.assertEquals(3, v2.patch) self.assertTrue(v2.is_prerelease()) self.assertEquals('beta', v2.label) self.assertEquals('07.17.2014', v2.meta) def test_major_comparison_as_long(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 1, 100) v2 = semver.Version(2, 0, 0) self.assertGreater(v2.as_long(), v1.as_long()) def test_minor_comparison_as_long(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 1, 10) v2 = semver.Version(1, 2, 1) self.assertGreater(v2.as_long(), v1.as_long()) def test_patch_comparison_as_long(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 1, 1) v2 = semver.Version(1, 1, 100) self.assertGreater(v2.as_long(), v1.as_long()) def test_label_comparison_as_long(self): v1 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0, 'alpha') v2 = semver.Version(1, 0, 0) self.assertGreater(v2, v1)

commit_message:
Partial revert of putting bare-metal in repo roles

Bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ironic/+bug/1429962
in ubuntu repo will cause our repo tests to fail.
To allow progress while this gets fixed, pulling bare-metal
conductor from the os-compute-worker role.

The other bare-metal patches for the cookbook should also get in to
allow clean tests to be run.

Change-Id: I936d90a93141402aac0639576da04fd4e2c8752e
Related-Bug: #1429245

commit_message:
Set umask to 0022 for OCF scripts that add network namespaces

When ns_haproxy or ns_IPaddr2 create the first network namespace
/var/run/netns will have permissions of 751 due to the umask
being 0026 at that time. This will cause the problems with
Neutron agents described in the referenced bug.

Change-Id: Ib8d1f485272ef843e935f43b1b40d7db6b0c2e78
Closes-bug: #1414239

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a for interacting with Github. import base64 import getpass import json import random import re import string import httplib2 class GitHubAuth(object): username = None password = None full_repo_name = None git_url = None _token = None _auth_url = 'https://api.github.com/authorizations' def __init__(self, git_url): self.git_url = git_url user_org_name, repo = '', '' github_regex = r'github\.com[:/](.+?)/(.+?)($|/$|\.git$|\.git/$)' repo_pat = re.compile(github_regex) match = repo_pat.search(self.git_url) if match: user_org_name, repo = match.group(1), match.group(2) else: raise ValueError("Failed to parse %s." % git_url) self.full_repo_name = '/'.join([user_org_name, repo]) prompt = ("Username for repo '%s' [%s]:" % (self.full_repo_name, user_org_name)) username = raw_input(prompt) or user_org_name password = getpass.getpass("Password: ") self.username = username self.password = password @property def _auth_header(self): authstring = '%s:%s' % (self.username, self.password) auth = base64.encodestring(authstring) return { 'Authorization': 'Basic %s' % auth, 'Content-Type': 'application/json', } @property def token(self): if self._token is None: self._get_repo_token() return self._token def _get_repo_token(self): note = ''.join(random.sample(string.lowercase, 5)) auth_info = { 'scopes': 'repo', 'note': 'Solum-status-%s' % note, } resp, content = httplib2.Http().request( self._auth_url, 'POST', headers=self._auth_header, body=json.dumps(auth_info)) if resp.get('status') in ['200', '201']: response_body = json.loads(content) self._token = response_body.get('token') def create_webhook(self, trigger_uri): hook_url = ('https://api.github.com/repos/%s/hooks' % self.full_repo_name) hook_info = { 'name': 'web', 'events': ['pull_request', 'commit_comment'], 'config': { 'content_type': 'json', 'url': trigger_uri, } } resp, content = httplib2.Http().request( hook_url, 'POST', headers=self._auth_header, body=json.dumps(hook_info)) if resp.get('status') not in ['200', '201']: pass def add_ssh_key(self, public_key=None, is_private=False): if not public_key: return api_url = ('https://api.github.com/repos/%s/keys' % self.full_repo_name) if is_private: api_url = 'https://api.github.com/user/keys' key_info = { 'title': 'devops@Solum', 'key': public_key, } resp, content = httplib2.Http().request( api_url, 'POST', headers=self._auth_header, body=json.dumps(key_info)) if resp.get('status') not in ['200', '201']: pass

commit_message:
Trim ansible's output to console.log

Since I2786f73334b99bfa98d344c50337c86f75fae273 ansible's output is
logged properly to a file and published at the end of a gate check.
This trims the output from ansible to the console to make the console
log that is published far shorter and easier to read.

Co-Authored-By: Ian Cordasco <ian.cordasco@rackspace.com>
Change-Id: I98fb57a56c1b7ddd6558e265cf6e65b159a05123
Partial-bug: 1425482
(cherry picked from commit a9244537d62662ab3342d1c1bdb74e3b1f23ad0e)

added_lines: # Set-up our tiny awk script. strip_debug=" !/(^[ 0-9|:.-]+<[0-9.]|localhost+>)|Extracting/ { gsub(/{.*/, \"\"); gsub(/\\n.*/, \"\"); gsub(/\=\>.*/, \"\"); print } " source $(dirname ${0})/run-playbooks.sh > ansible-logs.tmp awk "${strip_debug}" < ansible-logs.tmp rm -f ansible-logs.tmp

commit_message:
Restore minimum requirement version for kombu

Commit 499db6b64071c2afa16390ad2bc024e6a96db4ff capped anything that
didn't have an upper bound for stable/juno using what was currently
tested in the gate from pip-freeze output.

However, it pinned kombu at 3.0.7 when it was >= 2.5.0 before which
breaks anyone that's already shipped a Juno-based distribution with the
level of packages required in the last release (2014.2.2).

This change restores the lower bound on kombu and makes 3.0.7 the upper
bound but not the only required version.

Going through the other == pins in commit 499db6b64 the only other one
is suds but it pins on what was already the minimum required version,
0.4, so that was OK.

Change-Id: I8bb1c2a752156271a88b832863b1b6fc26e61e7f

commit_message:
Fixed issues while using --bypass-url

Python-troveclient 1.0.8 introduced a regression where the usage
of --bypass-url results in an AuthSystemNotFound exception.
Removing some redundant code, which was due to a previous merge
conflict, fixed the issue.

Closes-bug 1416120

Change-Id: I1c949f69ee08447ce88aeefa92c60f361ab54832

commit_message:
Added helper scripts

1) bulk-delete can be used to delete apps or assemblies
   in bulk

2) observe-assembly can be used to monitor status of an
   assembly

Both scripts assume that the required environment variables, such
as auth_token, auth_url, etc. are correctly set.

Change-Id: I4c903e0db46d3094fa3b02c27ebbcecaedd567a1

added_lines: #!/bin/bash if [ $# -lt 1 ]; then echo "./observe-assembly.sh <assembly-name>" exit 0 fi name=$1 t1=`date +%s` while true do status=`solum assembly show $name | awk '{print $4}' | head -4 | tail -1` echo "Status:$status" if [ $status = "READY" ]; then break fi solum assembly show $name sleep 5 done t2=`date +%s` total_time=$((t2-t1)) echo "Time to deploy assembly:$total_time seconds" echo "Assembly details:" solum assembly show $name

commit_message:
Make service_create return 400 with invalid json manifest

Currently when service_create is passed an invalid
json formatted manifest, 500 status is returned
to user due to unhandled ValueError exception.
This patch handles this exception and return 400
status to user when invalid manifest is passed.

Change-Id: I8a4b7ab9217947b56db625c66164c19865f113fc
Closes-bug: #1429757

commit_message:
Fix bash autocompletion of "rally task sla_check"

Character "_" is used as delimiter of commands and
their subcommands stored in bash array as keys,
i.e. in form "task_sla_check". Current code splits
it into an array based on delimiter "_" which would
return array with three values - task, sla and check.
The patch takes first value from the beginning to
first "_" as command and the rest as its subcommand.

Change-Id: I7d8c9b1eeb7c28ef24b0f2f366c6a18930282be5
Closes-bug: 1401180
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/44/162744/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add test_sahara_create_delete_job_binary test method

Adding test method that checks creating/removal of job binary under
Project/Data Processing/Job Binaries.
The core testing function can be easily extended with other job binary
templates; the initial versions allows to test for jobs stored on the
Internal DB.

As part of this test several items have been created
* new pageobject class JobbinariesPage
* new form field FileInputFormFieldRegion

Co-Authored-By: Luigi Toscano <ltoscano@redhat.com>
Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing

Change-Id: I48c992bbfd0b2428be220a4462d5ef76aca5fa45

Add simple test for page under /Project/Data Processing/Image Registry,
that registers and unregisters an image in the Sahara registry.

Infrastructure changes needed by the test:
 - new page object with basic handling of the Image Registry page;
 - new ssh_user config option with the cloud-init username for the
   image (named after the corresponding tempest option);
 - new parameter in get_row() table method for exact match.

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing
Co-Authored-By: Luigi Toscano <ltoscano@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I1e389f0baff655f8f06a0a6cbb4a10b9a68dd444
'}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-02-27 14:49:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/b40ac3892d95077c416c6401281e89451648ead1', 'message': 'Add test_sahara_image_registry

Add simple test for page under /Project/Data Processing/Image Registry,
that registers and unregisters an image in the Sahara registry.

Infrastructure changes needed by the test:
 - new page object with basic handling of the Image Registry page;
 - new ssh_user config option with the cloud-init username for the
   image (named after the corresponding tempest option);
 - new parameter in get_row() table method for exact match;
 - add "wait-until-active" method for the Image page;
 - enable sahara service by default in horizon.conf.

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing
Co-Authored-By: Luigi Toscano <ltoscano@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I1e389f0baff655f8f06a0a6cbb4a10b9a68dd444
'}, {'number': 14, 'created': '2015-03-05 10:36:44.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/pages/project/data_processing/imageregistrypage.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/config.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/regions/tables.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/horizon.conf', 'openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/tests/test_sahara_image_registry.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/pages/project/compute/imagespage.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/7b16bbf920963cb5cf915c4d79d4cc77cc1781cf', 'message': 'Add test_sahara_image_registry

Infrastructure changes needed by the test:

 - new ssh_user config option with the cloud-init username for the

 - new parameter in get_row() table method for exact match;
 - add "wait-until-active" method for the Image page;
 - enable sahara service by default in horizon.conf.

Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing
Co-Authored-By: Luigi Toscano <ltoscano@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I1e389f0baff655f8f06a0a6cbb4a10b9a68dd444

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests import helpers from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests.tests import decorators NEW_PASSWORD = "123" @decorators.services_required("sahara") class TestImageRegistry(helpers.TestCase): IMAGE_NAME = "cirros" USER_NAME = "cirros" def test_image_register_unregister(self): image_pg = self.home_pg.go_to_dataprocessing_imageregistrypage() image_pg.register_image(self.IMAGE_NAME, self.USER_NAME, "Test description") self.assertFalse(image_pg.is_error_message_present()) image_pg.unregister_image(self.IMAGE_NAME) self.assertFalse(image_pg.is_error_message_present())

commit_message:
Create and upload heat test images to tarballs

This change will only create a fedora image but a future change could
also generate images for Ubuntu and CentOS7.

build-heat-test-image.sh requires an installed diskimage-builder,
so the recipe for diskimage-builder-install was determined by running
build-heat-test-image.sh in a pristine trusty cloud image.

Change-Id: I03a9efe47fc3f21471a57e33ab09b0d7a13b219c

commit_message:
Make the kolla-functional job to be voting

* Add kolla-functional job to the gate pipeline
* Make kolla-functional job to be voting in both check and
gate pipelines

implements blueprint: rabbitmq-gating

Change-Id: I5de122be3ace65ea4bcbf24f4fddf569fdd92efb

commit_message:
Add missing "plus" symbol to the firwall Add Policy button

Updated the AddPolicyLink class to add the attribute "icon" with a
value of "plus" to fix the inconsistency referred in the bug

Change-Id: I9d8efae871c120858019077c3a1f56ae09918be4
Closes-Bug: #1429655

commit_message:
Bump glance_store to 0.2.0

Version 0.2.0 glance_store library has content that glance server
plans on leveraging. The release adds support for store capabilities
as enabled by glance blueprint store-capabilities (Change
I7cc3756535d09a6804ba02a23c86af13b8e9cd1a ) and helps us bump up the version here.

Change-Id: I5055b837e94fdee7e01cc94f8bdb89bada34f77b
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Include readonly flag in metadef API

Current API does not return readonly flag for properties included when
querying for metadef namespaces. The readonly field is included in both
the spec and the schema definition, so it should be returned in API
results as well.

DocImpact
APIImpact

Change-Id: I0db4491e8b44c8aa591a21fd95c7a0713bff9d4c
Closes-Bug: 1406235

commit_message:
Adds openSUSE in the installing documentation

Change-Id: Ic8a19d9fd1d6d551b9ca2ee36389c69e63cf0869
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/83/129283/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: openSUSE, SLE ############# openSUSE 13.2, SLE 12, and the rolling release Factory needs an extra repository enabled to install all the OpenStack packages. Search the proper repository in the `Cloud:OpenStack:Master <https://build.opensuse.org/project/repositories/Cloud:OpenStack:Master>`_ project. For example, for openSUSE 13.2: 1. Add the OpenStack master repository:: $ sudo zypper ar -f -g http://download.opensuse.org/repositories/Cloud:/OpenStack:/Master/openSUSE_13.2/ OpenStack $ sudo zypper ref 2. Install Glance:: $ sudo zypper in openstack-glance openSUSE, SLE ############# On openSUSE and SLE (also this is valid for Factory), we can install all the build dependencies using Zypper. 1. Install Git and build dependencies:: $ sudo zypper install git $ sudo zypper source-install -d openstack-glance .. note:: If you want to build the Glance documentation locally, you will also want to install the packages python-sphinx and graphviz. 2. Clone Glance's trunk branch from GitHub:: $ git clone git://github.com/openstack/glance $ cd glance 3. Install Glance:: $ sudo python setup.py install

commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections. Hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection. Because of this problem, the green thread is not released
back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

DocImpact:
Added http_keepalive option (default=True).

SecurityImpact

Closes-Bug: #1361360
Change-Id: I93aaca24935a4f3096210233097dd6b8c5440176

commit_message:
Attempt to see what happens with close-fds patch

Update oslo incubator code to the close-fd patch
code to see what impact this has on nova and to
see if this is a safe (non-breaking) patch to
accept.

Depends-On: If5aa626f76dd5068860eef09560a383334fc674c

Change-Id: If5aa626f76dd5068860eef09560a383334fc674c

commit_message:
Adding glusterfs job to Cinder's check pipeline (non voting)

As we are able to run 'gate-tempest-dsvm-full-glusterfs' job
successfully in experimental mode without any failures, promoting
this job to check (non voting) pipeline for Cinder and
stackforge/devstack-plugin-glusterfs projects.

Co-Authored-By: Deepak C Shetty <deepakcs@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iedb7fafb96d8d98c77085ce2b204d50a4e0686b5

commit_message:
Setup /etc/hosts for aiopcpu

Since nova uses hostnames for live migration make sure all nodes can
resolve the hostnames of other hosts.

Change-Id: I81ef25af8a3b6b17887353856fb60ccd81a30e13

commit_message:
zuul-swift-upload place mime icon into cell

The mime icons were not correctly placed in the table cell causing
them to appear above the table (eg:
http://logs.openstack.org/16/155516/1/check/check-dg-tempest-dsvm-full/c0853a4/index.html)

Put in the missing <td> tags.

Change-Id: Icdae38d55a6dd9472c382006bae9addf3ef6010b

Mount the first partition.
Print out the location of the mount.

commit_message:
Move neutron api job definition to neutron.yaml

The convention seems to be including job definitions for a given
project in a single file rather than requiring a file per job
definition, so this change moves the neutron api job definition to
neutron.yaml.

Change-Id: I47649b3137a8ad15e29e521c786cee34a0de05ea

Add functional test job for python-neutronclient

Create a functional test job for python-neutronclient, set as non-voting
until its working. The neutronclient functional tests wil come from the
tempest cli tests.

Related-Bug: #1429289

subject: Disable gate-oslo-incubator-python34 for Icehouse
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-04 16:32:50.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/53bf44fef8e976f0746f0135a2c8301e445f9c43', 'message': 'Disable gate-oslo-incubator-python34 for Icehouse

The job was broken by recent switch from py33 to py34 jobs. Precise
images do not contain latest python version, and fail now.

As per oslo team,

"The incubator python 3 job was added to help us port incubated code to
python 3 before graduating it. We won't be graduating modules from the
stable branch, so as long as none of the consuming projects have python
3 jobs on their stable branches we can just drop the icehouse python 3
job for oslo-incubator."

I don't know of any consumers that actually use code from oslo-incubator
and at the same time support py3, so disabling the job for the branch.

Change-Id: Ia8f5fac1d37a0ce8062ba144da9c3adcf9a474a3
'}]
commit_message:
Disable gate-oslo-incubator-python34 for Icehouse

The job was broken by recent switch from py33 to py34 jobs. Precise
images do not contain latest python version, and fail now.

As per oslo team,

"The incubator python 3 job was added to help us port incubated code to
python 3 before graduating it. We won't be graduating modules from the
stable branch, so as long as none of the consuming projects have python
3 jobs on their stable branches we can just drop the icehouse python 3
job for oslo-incubator."

I don't know of any consumers that actually use code from oslo-incubator
and at the same time support py3, so disabling the job for the branch.

Change-Id: Ia8f5fac1d37a0ce8062ba144da9c3adcf9a474a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/03/161303/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: ^(gate|check)-oslo-incubator-python34$ branch: ^(?!stable/icehouse).*$

commit_message:
Replacing data_processing with data-processing

Using data_processing when setting keystone static catalog causes
Sahara not to find the endpoint afterwards since keystone translates
data_processing to data-processing.

Change-Id: I5b253e4f5a0486913c59150d2bafd631f06a8cf1
Partial-bug: #1356053

commit_message:
Add tests for subprocesses and deserialization

- Add a new section "shell_injection" to the config file.
- Read subprocess functions from config in "injection_shell.py".
- Check all process-starting calls in "injection_wildcard.py".
- Avoid double-counting of subprocess.Popen(shell=True) and others.
- Check for cPickle and marshal.
- Don't flag `pickle.dumps`, since `import pickle` triggers a message.
- Update a handful of examples and tests.

Change-Id: I041c7d8a30658b177e88d1664bb9dcf08367d7f7

commit_message:
Consistently use oslo_config.cfg.CONF

Keystone modules used different sources of the CONF global so were
inconsistent. All modules should use CONF from oslo_config.cfg. The
original sweep through the source:
I60c8d2c577d37b9b8a367b46596154ce6c49fff4

Change-Id: Ida9c42a724adb510619b0a250bedace579ae09c4

commit_message:
Add job runtime system package and database setup

This is an initial step toward combining the bare and devstack nodes
into a common type, by pulling package installation and database
configuration into the job runtime. It also adds an experimental job
to test-drive these features.

Change-Id: I47bd65e91323779a251ec231c748cb848d745e08

commit_message:
Unify using six.moves.range rename everywhere

Mainly to improve consistency, use range() from six.moves
renames across glance.

Behaves consistently like py2 xrange() and py3 range().

Removes unnecessary range() from glace/api/v2/images.py

Change-Id: Id21f923d05600b902f2239e25ef01716c07e74a3

commit_message:
Propose projects.yaml normalization daily

Add a job that will propose a change (or update a change) to
normalize projects.yaml, and run it once daily.  Normalization,
in this case, chiefly means removing un-used upstream lines
from projects.yaml (but will also catch minor YAML errors and
line wrapping).

Also simplify the proposal node regex.

Change-Id: I6520dfcd6f523886aba352f9bd7f9186cfeed84a

commit_message:
add option to store raw notification

- this patch adds ability to store raw notification. it does not
support indexing/querying against it as this is not expected to be
performant.
- use conf fixture to ensure test isolation.

Change-Id: Ic35bb81d1ed1b538280cb9c2e87aced22bdff207

commit_message:
Create our own rally job for ec2-api

In previous review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/159138/
I tried to use existing rally job. But I skipped fact that in this job
ec2-api wouldn't loaded. Now I was trying to think up how this existing
job can be adapted to load ec2-api plugin. And simple way to do it -
is to create another job-template with needed shell script and needed params.

Change-Id: I3a95b298a70795601ef4002fc413e91960af0f2b

commit_message:
Remove support for 3.3

We don't test against 3.3 in the integrated CI anymore
so we likely shouldn't say that we support it anymore
since it's not something we are guaranteeing.

We still support 3.4 (and that's what we are testing
against so we use that version in the setup.cfg
file).

Change-Id: I9fadcac92ea3f43e811818cf013f93445ec1b5e9

commit_message:
'Assignment' has no attr 'get_domain_by_name'

The domain API has moved to the resource manager. While there are
redirects at the manager level so that most calls won't notice,
keystone-manage mapping_purge is making a direct driver call (bypassing
the manager). It needs to be updated to point to the resource manager
rather than the assignment manager.

Change-Id: Ia4fc89a0496bf9dc45300dbbe4cb776210340de4
Closes-Bug: 1427379
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/43/161543/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone import resource resource_manager = resource.Manager() return resource_manager.driver.get_domain_by_name(name)['id']
deleted_lines: from keystone import assignment assignment_manager = assignment.Manager() return assignment_manager.driver.get_domain_by_name(name)['id']

commit_message:
Add packaging for Docker containers

In order to safely package containers, yum update -y
was added to each container.
Containers are now built and stored in an archive,
which is packed into a new rpm fuel-docker-images.

blueprint package-docker-images

Change-Id: Ib583e41ec07c9d60eb993216c00ef2f0ba2ca110

added_lines: define build_repo find $(BUILD_DIR)/packages/rpm/RPMS -name '*.rpm' -exec cp -u {} $(LOCAL_MIRROR_CENTOS_OS_BASEURL)/Packages \; createrepo -g $(LOCAL_MIRROR_CENTOS_OS_BASEURL)/comps.xml \ -o $(LOCAL_MIRROR_CENTOS_OS_BASEURL) $(LOCAL_MIRROR_CENTOS_OS_BASEURL) endef $(eval $(call build_repo)) $(ACTION.TOUCH) $(BUILD_DIR)/packages/rpm/fuel-docker-images.done: $(eval $(call prepare_file_source,fuel-docker-images,$(DOCKER_ART_NAME),$(BUILD_DIR)/docker/$(DOCKER_ART_NAME))) $(eval $(call build_rpm,fuel-docker-images)) $(eval $(call build_repo))

commit_message:
Fix path of RST locale file

locale files in RST folders are under $DOCNAME/source/locale/, fix one
error.

Also, small refactor of an condition.

Change-Id: I9a61b2d0e26bd19e2b0c1b8b95b2369530b05fcf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/02/162702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: case "${SPECIAL_BOOKS["${DOCNAME}"]}" in RST) IS_RST=1 ;; skip) continue ;; esac --source-file ${DocFolder}/${DOCNAME}/source/locale/${DOCNAME}.pot \
deleted_lines: if [ ${SPECIAL_BOOKS["${DOCNAME}"]} == "RST" ] ; then IS_RST=1 fi if [ ${SPECIAL_BOOKS["${DOCNAME}"]} == "skip" ] ; then continue fi --source-file ${DocFolder}/${DOCNAME}/locale/${DOCNAME}.pot \

commit_message:
Agent configuration and BIND9 improvements

* Make sure BIND9 rndc addzone/delzone compatiblity is maintained
by stripping the trailing dot on zone names
* Write out non-relativized zone files
* Add a transfer-source option to the Agent for AXFRs
* Add a query-destination option to the Agent BIND9 Backend
* Remove the 1 second sleep, as the Pool Manager should be able to recover

Change-Id: Ief7483d477affd17a13139f591dfe94be8285b74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/62/158462/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #transfer_source = None#query_destination = 127.0.0.1

subject: Print instance UUID to log
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-16 15:29:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/2444b2359b0a4cbc41083f05e394a4ad0b6f40c1', 'message': 'Print instance UUID to log

This macro allows a job running on a cloud instance to print the
UUID of that instance to the build log.  Often times when a system or
networking error occurs which causes the test to fail, it is only
detected after the job completes and the node has already been deleted.
By recording the instance UUID in an easy-to-find location, there is at
least a chance that someone can use the UUID to find the physical host
the instance was hosted on and do some analysis at that level.

Change-Id: Iddcd56e2e2f2a942573a9868d1c009106b38564a
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-02-26 05:54:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/277a23477d1ea26691bd8f9b2da7d4f0723fbba0', 'message': 'Print instance UUID to log

This macro allows a job running on a cloud instance to print the
UUID of that instance to the build log.  Often times when a system or
networking error occurs which causes the test to fail, it is only
detected after the job completes and the node has already been deleted.
By recording the instance UUID in an easy-to-find location, there is at
least a chance that a user can find someone who can use the UUID to find
the physical host the instance was hosted on and do some analysis at that
level.

Depends-On: Ib84ec30b5c4c5de5d5be80cae2b4230c1aba3bc6
Change-Id: Iddcd56e2e2f2a942573a9868d1c009106b38564a
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-02-26 06:07:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/aa8b1890e306886a0053d3ee6ebb805eb7ee3de4', 'message': 'Print instance UUID to log

This macro allows a job running on a cloud-based instance to print the
UUID of that instance to the build log.  By the time it is determined
that a test failed due to a system or networking error, the instance
has already been deleted.  The UUID can be used to locate the physical
system the instance ran on so that analysis can be done at that level.
By providing it in the build log, users will not have to find someone
with access to the nodepool logs to get this level of support for this
type of issue.

Depends-On: Ib84ec30b5c4c5de5d5be80cae2b4230c1aba3bc6
Change-Id: Iddcd56e2e2f2a942573a9868d1c009106b38564a
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-02-26 13:33:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/4c63ff904a0e00e168064a3068f0a2e8dddfd44d', 'message': 'Print instance UUID to log

This macro allows a job running on a cloud-based instance to print the
UUID of that instance to the build log.  By the time it is determined
that a test failed due to a system or networking error, the instance
has already been deleted.  The UUID can be used to locate the physical
system the instance ran on so that analysis can be done at that level.
By providing it in the build log, users will not have to find someone
with access to the nodepool logs to get this level of support for this
type of issue.

Depends-On: Ib84ec30b5c4c5de5d5be80cae2b4230c1aba3bc6
Change-Id: Iddcd56e2e2f2a942573a9868d1c009106b38564a
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-02-26 22:11:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/a2ae492e2e2bde479970c3849c7c2bd1ac73c9fe', 'message': 'Print instance UUID to log

This macro allows a job running on a cloud-based instance to print the
UUID of that instance to the build log.  By the time it is determined
that a test failed due to a system or networking error, the instance
has already been deleted.  The UUID can be used to locate the physical
system the instance ran on so that analysis can be done at that level.
By providing it in the build log, users will not have to find someone
with access to the nodepool logs to get this level of support for this
type of issue.

commit_message:
Print instance UUID to log

This macro allows a job running on a cloud-based instance to print the
UUID of that instance to the build log.  By the time it is determined
that a test failed due to a system or networking error, the instance
has already been deleted.  The UUID can be used to locate the physical
system the instance ran on so that analysis can be done at that level.
By providing it in the build log, users will not have to find someone
with access to the nodepool logs to get this level of support for this
type of issue.

Depends-On: Ib84ec30b5c4c5de5d5be80cae2b4230c1aba3bc6
Change-Id: Iddcd56e2e2f2a942573a9868d1c009106b38564a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/52/156252/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - builder: name: print-uuid builders: - shell: | #!/bin/sh export INSTANCE_UUID=`curl --connect-timeout 15 -s 169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/meta_data.json | python -c 'import sys, json; print json.load(sys.stdin)["uuid"]' 2>/dev/null` [ -n "${INSTANCE_UUID}" ] && echo "Instance UUID: ${INSTANCE_UUID}"

commit_message:
Fix dhcp config dir removed too soon

The config dir is now removed after unplugging.
This patch also mocks out shutil.rmtree in all dhcp tests.

Change-Id: I68faacbb820957fa0bece7003676bd981c56de58
Closes-Bug: 1429559

commit_message:
Add gate-tempest-dsvm-full-trove

Because trove builds on the compute base layer, it does not need
to be tested in all devstack-gate tests.  Instead, create a new
job that tests trove in a devstack environment as a first step
in removing it from the standard configuration.

Specify that TROVE should be enabled in the devstack updown job
so that the parts that enable trove are exercised in devstack.
This is already currently the case, but this updates the job config
so that it will continue to do so later when we remove trove from
the default config.

Change-Id: Ib503e45b08edfb2252d7c56af14f97d630e137d8

commit_message:
Add fuel-centos-build container for fuel/centos

fuel/centos will now be built from CentOS6
container dynamically with current package set
instead of being periodically rebuilt. It uses
ami-creator, which only runs on CentOS. It is
run inside Docker so it can be used on an
Ubuntu build host. After the image is created,
img2docker loads the content into Docker as a
Docker image.

Consolidates save/load to a single archive
instead of rolling up separate container tar
files.

Note that fuel-centos.done target depends on
RPM package build to avoid race conditions
where repo metadata is updated while base image
is being built.

Change-Id: I62abc07e79847b5c69eaa1a983575b214ebed649
Closes-Bug: #1336911
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/86/155686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

#fuel/centos-docker-build FROM centos:centos6 MAINTAINER Matthew Mosesohn mmosesohn@mirantis.com RUN echo -e "[nailgun]
name=Nailgun Local Repo
baseurl=http://$(route -n | awk '/^0.0.0.0/ { print $2 }'):_PORT_/os/x86_64/
gpgcheck=0" > /etc/yum.repos.d/nailgun.repo;yum clean all;yum --quiet install -y sudo ami-creator livecd-tools python-imgcreate python-setuptools ADD start.sh /usr/local/bin/start.sh ADD fuel-centos.ks /root/fuel-centos.ks RUN chmod 755 /usr/local/bin/start.sh RUN sed -i '/requiretty/s/^/#/g' /etc/sudoers;touch /etc/sysconfig/network;mkdir -p /var/lib/hiera && touch /var/lib/hiera/common.yaml #Replace repo and port in makefile RUN sed -i "s/^url .*/url --url=http://$(route -n | awk '/^0.0.0.0/ { print $2 }'):_PORT_/os/x86_64//" /root/fuel-centos.ks RUN sed -i "s/^repo .*/repo --name='Nailgun' --baseurl=http://$(route -n | awk '/^0.0.0.0/ { print $2 }'):_PORT_/os/x86_64//" /root/fuel-centos.ks CMD ["/usr/local/bin/start.sh"]

commit_message:
Notification Support for Metadata Definitions

We are proposing to support notifications for events on the
Metadata Definitions Catalog.

Implements: blueprint metadefs-notifications

Change-Id: I73a0921b8cf66cbaeffed285fcbc04a9aaee3c43
Co-Authored-By: Lakshmi N Sampath <lakshmi.sampath@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kamil Rykowski <kamil.rykowski@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/00/149500/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Notification Support for Metadata Definitions ============================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/metadefs-notifications This blueprint adds metadata definition notification support. The implemented juno spec for metadata notifications is here for reference: https://github.com/openstack/glance-specs/blob/master/specs/juno/metadata-schema-catalog.rst Problem description =================== Metadata definition resources - namespaces, objects, properties, tags, and resource types - don't provide any notification events when certain operations are fired on them. This doesn't allow for any intelligent caching of the data, meaning that the only opportunity for catalog users to be aware of changes is to continually poll. Polling is not performant for catalog users and puts extra load on the API and database. Proposed change =============== We are proposing to support notifications for events on the Metadata Definitions Catalog. This implementation will include the following events that will be triggered when necessary: * metadef_namespace.create - namespace has been created * metadef_namespace.update - namespace has been updated * metadef_namespace.delete - namespace has been deleted * metadef_object.create - object has been created * metadef_object.update - object has been updated * metadef_object.delete - object has been deleted * metadef_property.create - property has been created * metadef_property.update - property has been updated * metadef_property.delete - property has been deleted * metadef_tag.create - tag has been created * metadef_tag.update - tag has been updated * metadef_tag.delete - tag has been deleted * metadef_resource_type.create - resource type has been added to namespace * metadef_resource_type.delete - resource type has been removed from namespace In addition we will add a new configuration option to allow for disabling individual notifications. It will be a comma separated list with the following syntax: disabled_notifications = <type>.<action> For example, the following would disable all tag notification and property deletions: disabled_notifications = metadef_tag,metadef_property.delete The notifier will read this configuration and ignore notifications that are in the disabled list. The reason for this proposed addition is that we aren't sure whether or not tag notifications could get too chatty for some reason. Therefore, we'd like to give an option for deployers to disable it. Alternatives ------------ No notification support could be added. In this event, constant polling for changes could be done. The constant polling would lead to both latency in getting updates and extra load on the API and database. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- No external API impacts will be visible. The API itself will have a notifier added as part of the call. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- A notifier will be added to the REST API calls. The notifications listed above will be added. A new configuration option will be added to disable specific notifications. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Additional notifications will be generated, but the amount of changes to metadata definitions are not anticipated to be enough to impact performance. However we want to add the new disabled_notifications configuration option to allow operators to disable the notifications if they determine that are too chatty. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will have to setup listeners to received notification on metadefs if they desire them. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kamil-rykowski Other contributors: none Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): jokke Other reviewer(s): lakshmi-sampath travis-tripp Work Items ---------- Changes would be made to: #. Glance v2 metadef APIs to add notifiers #. notifer #. gateway Dependencies ============ Need to sync openstack/common from oslo-incubator for service module. https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1413861 Testing ======= Unit tests will be added for all possible code with a goal of being able to isolate functionality as much as possible. Tempest tests will be added wherever possible. Documentation Impact ==================== Docs needed for new notification usage References ========== `Current glance metadata definition catalog documentation. <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/metadefs-concepts.html>`_

commit_message:
Remove extra semicolon from mapping fixtures

In some of the objects from mapping fixtures there were extra semicolons
in the end of some keys (attributes), which were causing to output empty
values once the mapping rules were being applied.

Change-Id: I7dce7322a2670495aac7dff3d0076582911a28d6
